PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chipp (from 90 citizens) and Zakharov (from 180 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide-spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85 per cent of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care.
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985.
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Messner (from 132 citizens) and Teague (from 102 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they so wish to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Provision of Aids for Disabled People Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners urgently request The Honourable Senator Grimes, Minister for Community Services, to include Communication Aids on the equipment list funded through the `Provision of Aids for Disabled People' programme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will faciliate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
A. Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

B. Implementing national recycling programs to re-use water, and to compost into hygienic humus presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;
C. Developing national employment programs to give priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pre-School and Child Care Facilities: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
We deplore the proposed cut-back of funding for pre-school and child care in the mini-budget. We urge you to reverse proposals for cuts in children's services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS (GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:STATES GRANTS (PETROLEUM PRODUCTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that the Government wanted order of the day No. 1 and order of the day No. 2 dealt with cognately. I wonder whether it could get its act together.
—Is that so, Senator Grimes?
—We will debate them cognately as we frequently do. Either side can ask to do that.
—It is for the Government to decide how it wants its business conducted.
—What happened to you? Did you have a bad night?
—You seem to have had a bad night every day.
—Order! Could we get on with the debate? I understand that it is agreed that the two Bills be debated cognately.

—Thank you, Mr President. The Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill 1985 and the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill 1985 deal with matters which were part of the Government's May economic statement which the Opposition did not oppose. We welcomed the efforts of the Government in that statement to reduce government expenditures, even though we make no judgment about the priorities the Government adopted. That matter is the responsibility of the Government. Certainly, it was not the Opposition's intention then nor is it its intention now to oppose measures which give effect to that statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of these measures is the abolition of the liquefied petroleum gas subsidy which was introduced by the Fraser Government some time ago. It was introduced when the domestic price for LPG was very high and there were great discrepancies between those who were forced to use LPG and those who had access to natural gas and other cheaper sources of domestic heating. However, the situation has now changed. The domestic price of LPG is reasonably stable under the formula the Government has adopted, which we do not need to debate today, although the Opposition certainly would have some reservations about the Government's approach. Certainly some consumers will suffer as a result of this measure to abolish the subsidy. Under the present formula the benefit for consumers had fallen, but at least they were getting the benefit of something like $10 per annum at the wholesale level. As I said, it is estimated that the abolition of the subsidy will represent costs of that order for the average consumer. So it is a matter of some concern. However, the Opposition does not oppose this measure.

The States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill is also part of the May econ-omic statement, which emasculated the freight subsidy scheme and had a very serious impact on rural Australia. But as I have said, that is a priority the Government has adopted. It is no doubt consistent with the Government's general discriminatory attitude to rural Australia. That is the choice the Government has made about its expenditure controls. This Bill does not implement that change, but it is part and parcel of the Government's cost cutting arrangements. It is trying to tighten up what is left of that scheme which originally applied to some 4,000 locations around Australia where consumers received a freight subsidy. The new arrangements have reduced the number of those locations to about 1,650 and the Government estimates that it will save about $116m from this particular cost cutting priority which it has adopted.

It is interesting to note that in this Bill, which is trying to tighten up the administration of what is left of the scheme, the Government has been unable to identify any direct financial implications. That is a rather strange comment on the competence of the Government in its management of financial matters. However, there is one aspect of the Bill which the Opposition welcomes. In the other place we moved an amendment to widen the application of the scheme to mini-refineries around Australia other than the mini-refinery at Roma. Originally the Bill applied only to Roma and that is certainly the only mini-refinery that exists at present. However, there are moves to establish mini-refineries in other parts of Australia and, with the development of on-shore oil discoveries in very remote parts of Australia, it is likely that there will be further mini-refineries. Apparently this had not occurred to the Government when it drew up this particular provision. That again is an indication of its general ignorance of what is happening in remote parts of this country. The Opposition moved an amendment in the other place to rectify that, the Government supported it and that provision is now incorporated in the Bill. The Opposition welcomes that and does not oppose this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate briefly that the Australian Democrats are prepared to support the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill 1985. As Senator Durack has said, this is a Bill to withdraw a subsidy that was introduced in 1980 for a period of three years. That time has lapsed. The withdrawal of the subsidy will bring liquefied petroleum gas into line with all other petroleum products and this seems to be quite logical from our point of view. It will, of course, slightly disadvantage some people and unfortunately some of those will be country people. However, the Bill is introduced to withdraw the subsidy during the summer months so there will be quite a period during which adjustment can be made if there is hardship in any specific cases.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with any subsidy is that the day of reckoning always comes. There was a very good reason for introducing the subsidy back in 1980. There was a very sudden rise in costs of LPG and many people had equipped their homes to run on LPG. Suddenly they were caught with very steep increases in running costs. The subsidy has served a very useful purpose, but we think the day has come when that subsidy should be withdrawn. We are prepared to support the Government's initiative in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation and for their contributions to the debate. The Government believes that these measures were necessary and are an important part of rationalising the system of support in this country. We accept that there will be the same sorts of remarks about such legislation as those made by Senator Durack, but overall we are very pleased that we can get this legislation through. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY BILL 1985GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:WHEAT TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
Senator Grimes-May I suggest that we debate these Bills and the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill 1985 cognately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY BILL 1985GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing these Bills. The Wheat Tax Amendment Bill is pretty well a routine one and, although the Grain Legumes Levy Bill introduces new levies, they are along the same lines as those in the research Bills that come through this chamber annually. The rate of wheat tax, which is levied to fund industry research, is being increased from the current operative and maximum rate of 30c per tonne to a maximum rate of $1.10 per tonne. The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has indicated that it seeks an initial rise from 30c to 35c per tonne. I understand that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has not yet indicated agreement to that 35c operative rate for the current season, but I understand that that should be forthcoming shortly if it has not hapened in the last few days. Australian wheat growers would like that finalised pretty shortly so that they know which way they are going.

SPEECH.PARA: The Grain Legumes Levy Bill and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill are new Bills. They currently pertain to lupins and field peas. These are fast becoming crops in their own right within Australia rather than just rotational crops used specially for nitrogen replenishment. The legislation provides for an initial levy rate of 75c per tonne and that rate may be varied to a maximum of $2.60 per tonne. In all instances expenditure will be met with a dollar for dollar subsidy from the Commonwealth Government.

These research moneys are vital, particularly in the case of the wheat industry where the fund has run down because of drought in most of the major wheat producing areas. It is necessary that that fund be replenished. Research funds are used very much in the wheat industry, one of our great export industries; to identify and treat different types of soil deficiences. Research is carried out into disease, insect and rodent damage, plant breeding techniques, different plant varieties, storage, transport and so on. It plays quite a vital role in identifying problems and indicating treatment. It has the wholehearted support of the industry.

I point out that currently very little has been said by this Government about one of the `diseases' affecting all primary industry; namely, the current high interest rates. They are higher, possibly, in real terms than they were in the Depression and they are possibly the highest since Federation. It was quite ironic that at the weekend the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) made a statement which was much publicised, particularly throughout rural Australia. In question time on Tuesday he alluded to the fact that he was in Western Australia at the weekend and met the rural Press. He said that the Hawke Government had given more benefits to farmers than any government for decades. That statement reeks of another famous statement from a previous Labor Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, which has gone down in history in rural Australia. He said that the rural industries had never had it so good.

With all the financial measures introduced by this Government-financial statements, mini-Budgets, Budgets, tax statements and all the rest-not one of them has not disadvantaged the rural sector in some way, shape or form. It is ironic that the Minister for Finance would make such a statement and expect the people in the rural areas to believe him. It must be said that if, as the saying goes, the people in rural areas were living off the fat of the land, they could expect to pay more towards the common good. The fact is that they are not. It is also a fact that they are contributing up to 45 per cent of our export earnings while we are running a current account deficit of around $10 billion. I suspect that an industry such as that should be shepherded and looked after a little rather than be treated harshly as it has been treated in every financial measure that has been brought down by this Government. Apart from that little homily, the Opposition supports these rural Bills. They are necessary. They are routine Bills. As I said, the grain legume Bills are new, but they are in the same vein as Bills relating to other rural industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not oppose the Grain Legumes Levy Bill 1985, the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill 1985 and the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill 1985. In order to facilitate the passing of these Bills through the Committee stage, as I understand that there will be no amendments, I wish to raise a matter with regard to clause 12 (2) of the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill 1985 that I would normally raise in Committee. This matter was raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills with regard to some other pieces of primary industry legislation and, indeed, other legislation, in particular the Export Inspection Charges (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. The Committee found a problem in clause 20 of that Bill relating to the matter of self-incrimination. Clause 12 (2) of the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill) states that a person is not excused from submitting a return or providing information on the ground that it might tend to incriminate that person. However, it makes the qualifying comment that any return or information so submitted-that is, as required under the Act-or information which is provided under the Act is not admissible in evidence except in proceedings for the failure to submit a return or to provide information, or for the furnishing of information, or a return that is false or misleading in a material particular.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has written to the Scrutiny for Bills Committee on this matter reassuring members of that Committee, presumably also members of this Parliament and people in the community who are likely to be affected by this clause, that indeed there will be no use of the evidence against people if that evidence is furnished to the Department through the sorts of forms and other information garnering processes that are required under the Act. I would just like to say to the Minister that we will be keeping a weather eye on this matter. On the very first occasion that it comes to our attention that in fact this undertaking is broken, we will be taking steps perhaps through the statute law miscellaneous provisions legislation, or through some other means, to ensure that the sort of evidence which may incriminate somebody through providing information under this Act is no longer able to be used as evidence against them in any other area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators opposite for their support for this legislation. Apart from the fact that I grew up and still live in a semi-rural area, I do not claim to be the expert that my wheat growing colleague Senator Walsh is in this area. I listened with interest to what Senator Collard correctly described as his homily, which he usually gives during speeches of this type, even though he is not opposing the legislation. Perhaps I can give a little bit of a homily as a boy from the bush. I grew up in the post-war period when we heard from Senator--
—Is this going to be about your chooks again?

—No, not my chooks. I have given honourable senators plenty of talks about my chooks. We heard from members of what was then the Country Party, and in fact still claims to be the Country Party, that all the subsidies and all the provisions that were provided by government over the years had the aim of keeping people on the farm and the aim of maintaining decentralisation and stopping us from becoming a terrible, urban-based country. In that time the percentage of people in the rural areas has halved and I think the number of farmers is down to about a third. So those policies, quite clearly, did not succeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I also note with interest the debate recently amongst farmers and amongst people such as Mr Anthony and others, between the two wings of the rural movement at the moment-those who claim they believe in free enterprise and free markets, such as Mr McLachlan and company, and those who could be quite correctly described as agrarian socialists such as Senator Collard and others, who believe that all government expenditure is bad except government expenditure on farmers. I think it was Major Major's father in Catch-22 who used that definition. I think it is going to be interesting for those of us who are not directly involved to listen to the continuation of that debate.

Senator Collard raised the matter of what will be the operative rate for the wheat levy shortly. I was under the impression-I will get confirmation of this from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin)-certainly from one reading of the second reading speech and notes that in fact the Minister had agreed that the new operative rate would be 35c per tonne. I will check on that and make sure that that has been confirmed.

Senator Haines raised, as she always does, an important issue-the issue of the problem of self-incrimination which the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and others raised in considering the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill 1985. As she said, clause 12 (2) has the effect of removing self-incrimination as an excuse for refusing or failing to submit returns or to provide information required to be submitted or provided by the Bill. The research schemes which have been developed by this Bill and other Bills, in consultation with the relevant industry groups I might add, provide for the collection of a levy to finance the research into new and important crops.

The scheme relies absolutely upon the provision by receivers and the purchasers of grain legumes of returns containing true and correct particulars of deliveries made to them by growers. In addition, certain growers who process their own grain legumes are also obliged to submit returns. The amount of levy paid by receivers, purchasers and growers is checked against the information contained in the return. There is provision in the Bill for the receiver or purchaser to recover the amount paid on the grower's behalf. The alternative charging system of requiring each and every grower to submit levy payments and returns would not be administratively feasible or economically sensible. The Minister prefers that information be derived directly from the receiver or the purchaser. Virtually the entire revenue collection by the Department proceeds on this basis. If incrimination was available as an excuse in not providing the information, operations which infringed some provision of the Bill might not be recorded and returns would therefore be incomplete.

To encourage the provision of complete returns and to provide a safeguard against prosecution on the basis of information required by law to be recorded and handed over to the Government, sub-clause 12 (2) makes the information inadmissible in evidence except in specified kinds of proceedings relating to the return itself. In the Government's view, this provides a safeguard against prosecution on the basis of information contained in the return, while allowing the revenue collection functions to proceed and it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. However, the Government takes Senator Haines's point. We take the warning that she and her colleagues will be observing the operation of this measure very closely. I thank honourable senators for their interest and for their support of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or requests or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust (Boundaries) Bill is a small Bill seeking to validate certain necessary changes to the boundaries of this area of land. Normally the Opposition would not give it too much concern or attention, but because it relates to the handover of the Uluru area of Ayers Rock to a local community, the Opposition has a view which it wishes to express. I will be moving an amendment to the second reading expressing our concern about the way in which the Government has gone about these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a Bill for an Act relating to the boundaries of the land held under the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust, which is established under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The Petermann Land Trust was established by the Fraser Government and its boundaries were gazetted on 21 July 1978 when my colleague Senator Chaney I think, was, the relevant Minister. The proposed Bill has two purposes; first, to rationalise the boundaries of the Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mt Olga) National Park and the land granted under the Land Trust to ensure that the description of the Land Trust does not overlap. What has happened is that the land given under the Trust and the land in the national park do overlap. Some error was made in surveying, which was brought to light in 1978 when the Surveyor-General conducted a general survey in preparation for Northern Territory statehood. The Surveyor-General became aware that the boundaries were not correctly drawn.

This matter was referred to the Department of Administrative Services which, in its wisdom, did nothing. It did not advise the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; no action was taken to bring the boundaries into line as they should have been brought into line at that stage. The error has now come to light, and the Department of Administrative Services should explain why no action was taken for some five or seven years. If it was during the period of our stewardship and ministerial responsibility, it is for us to answer. Nevertheless, the Department of Administrative Services has let this go as something not terribly important.

The area of land involved is very small-about two square kilometres-but the error was brought to light some years ago. No action was taken and we want to know why. The matter now has to be dealt with with some speed, not least because the handover of the Uluru area to an Aboriginal community is imminent. We understand that the handover of title is to take place on 26 October. It is necessary to get this Bill passed so that the Government can proceed to prepare the final documents which will be required for the handover to take place on 26 October.

The Bill has only a few clauses. Clause 4, which seeks to validate the proclamation of the Uluru National Park, is not one that we wish to oppose. Clause 3, which is the significant clause of the Bill, seeks to determine the boundaries of the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust. It raises anew the question of the way in which the Government has proceeded on the handover of Uluru, particularly in relation to the lack of consultation with the Northern Territory Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have your second reading amendment?

—Senator Chipp has asked about the second reading amendment. I would be grateful if the attendants would circulate the second reading amendment now. I mention to Senator Chipp that we will be moving an amendment, to express our concern about the lack of consultation, as an attachment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Our opposition to clause 3, to which I have adverted, is consistent with the position we took when we debated the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill, which dealt with the transfer of title of Ayers Rock to a local Aboriginal community. We claimed at that stage that Ayers Rock was of significance to all Australians and that the transfer of title to a small community was inappropriate. We put our arguments at some length and the Senate determined its position. We said that the land should be vested in the Northern Territory with the provision of freehold title within the area as living areas for local Aboriginal communities. We said then that as a matter of principle the Northern Territory Government should have been consulted and we say again that it should have been consulted on any move to change the boundaries of the national park or of the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust covering the area.

If I may, I will say something about the proposed handover which is set down for the 26th and which is the reason for this Bill now being passed by the Parliament. It is probably an important event for certain Aboriginal people, but the Government is planning to spend an enormous amount of money celebrating it. I refer honourable senators to page 939, and a few following pages, of the Hansard record of the Senate Estimates Committee D hearing on 1 October. We asked officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs exactly how much was going to be spent in relation to the handover ceremony, and the answer was absolutely horrific. They advised that the catering for the ceremony will cost $22,000; that the co-ordination of Aboriginal arrangements for the ceremony will cost $30,000, that the assistance of a public relations firm to assist in media liaison will cost $80,000; that a pictorial book will cost $55,000; that pamphlets will cost $50,000 and that a public relations consultancy fee of $40,000 will be paid to Mr White.

Those amounts make up the more than $277,000 which has been set aside specifically for the handover ceremony. In addition, we were advised at the Estimates committee of an amount of $150,000 which related to the preparation of a film, only some of which could be attributed to the actual ceremony; some of it would have been spent anyhow. The cost of the handover of Ayers Rock is wrong in principle. The Government is planning to spend over $277,000 on the event-under the headings which I have read out and which were given to us in the Estimates committee when we asked for them-plus a proportion of the $150,000 set aside for the film. It will probably total well over $300,000, which is an inordinately large amount to expend. Some of it comes under the heading of propaganda. It is bad enough to have the handover taking place but it is doubly bad to have these other matters added to it. On behalf of the Opposition I move:
Leave out all words after `That', insert:

`the Senate declines to give this Bill a second reading because of its concern that the Northern Territory Government was not consulted in relation to the alterations to the boundaries of the Petermann Land Trust or its effect on the Uluru National Park at any stage prior to the introduction of the Bill into the Parliament'.

We believe as a matter of constitutional propriety, whether two square kilometres or 2,000 square kilometres is involved, that some consultation between governments was appropriate. Of course, if that consultation had taken place the amendment would have no force.

We condemn the Government for its failure to transfer ownership of the Uluru National Park to the Northern Territory. As Ayers Rock is a national symbol, it should not be vested in any section of the community but should remain the property of the nation. We express our regret-nothing stronger than that-that the office of the Governor-General is to be involved in the transfer of title to Uluru National Park in the full knowledge which the Government has, from survey evidence, that this transfer does not have the support of Australian people. Our amendment goes to proper constitutional practice and proper need for consultation. If the Government is determined not to consult with the Northern Territory, let it say so. That information will be noted in the Northern Territory. That is a matter for the Government to determine. Apart from our concern about clause 3, we have no objection to clause 4 of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are happy to facilitate the speedy passage of the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust (Boundaries) Bill 1985. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has explained, the Bill is designed to rectify a long standing misdescription of the boundaries of land granted to the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The misdescription, although minor in terms of the amount of land involved, had the effect of creating inconsistency between the common boundaries of the Petermann Aboriginal Reserve and the adjoining Uluru National Park. The Government is rightly concerned to remove any doubts or uncertainties which may arise as a result of this discrepancy before the historic handover ceremony of the Uluru National Park on 26 October-which, as I understand, the Liberal Party of Australia has announced that it will boycott. I think that is a shameful act, if that is true. It is an act which I would have thought could not have been more divisive at this time in the history of Australia. As my colleague Senator Macklin in describing the Bills effecting the handover, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only is this step of vital importance to the Aboriginal people themselves. It will be symbolic to the entire Australian community that we have started down a road which for this nation is historic-a road which ultimately will lead to a just settlement of the entire land rights issue.

I am surprised that Senator Peter Baume should be adopting this attitude, because his record as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was a distinguished one. He was one of the few Ministers who, along with Senator Chaney, showed real compassion and real understanding of the Aboriginal problem. Yet to bring in a divisive, petty little amendment like this I am sure is not of Senator Peter Baume's making or liking. It is one dictated by his political party which has got to pay some obeisance to those strange people who pose as Ministers in the Northern Territory. I find it ludicrous that the Liberal Party, at Federal level in this chamber, should move an amendment to the second reading of a Bill which states:
The Senate declines to give this Bill a second reading because of its concern that the Northern Territory Government was not consulted in relation to the alterations . . .
Good heavens! We are talking about a stretch of land only nine kilometres long by 200 metres wide.

That is all this is about. I pay Senator Peter Baume due credit. He did not answer my interjection, because there was no answer to it. He is asking the Federal Government to consult with this mishmash of Liberal politicians in the Northern Territory about a matter like this. Did the Northern Territory, with the same mishmash of Liberal politicians, consult with the Federal Government when it was mishandling and misappropriating millions of dollars in buying out a private enterprise casino? Was there any consultation with the Federal Government? Virtually all the money came from the Australian taxpayer. One would have thought that, out of sheer courtesy, the Northern Territory Government would have said to the Australian Treasurer or the Federal Parliament: `Look, we are going to do this with your money. Do you approve? Have you any fine tuning you wish to be made on this deal?' As I understand it, there was not one word of consultation. Yet one has to say this about the Liberal Party: It is loyal to the incredibly stupid people who pose under its name as politicians in other States. Here we have an Act by the Northern Territory Government, by the Country-Liberal Party, that borders on the improper. It did not consult the Federal Government about it. Yet in this debate, when we are about to do something perfectly logical and proper, simply to correct an earlier oversight-bearing in mind that an incredibly important occasion concerning the Aboriginal people is to take place on 26 October, namely the handing over of the Uluru National Park-all the Liberal Party can do is to say: `We will kill this Bill'. It does not even have the guts to say: `We disagree with it and we will vote against the second reading'. It is trying to bring in the subterfuge that it will decline to give the Bill a second reading only because there has been no consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will vote against the third reading.

—I am glad to hear that. It will at least be an honest manifestation of your feelings. I compliment you on it. It is a fair manifestation of your feelings. The amendment is a divisive and pathetic attempt to kill the Bill before the handover of the park on the 26th of this month. The Australian Democrats stand by the view expressed by Senator Macklin. We are pleased to support the correction of a minor technical discrepancy which might have adversely affected the handover of Uluru National Park.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are witnessing an attempt by the Opposition to delay and amend what is clearly a popular move by the Government to accept its responsibilities in respect of this project in the Northern Territory. It is clear that the Opposition, bereft of positive policies in respect of a whole range of issues, has seized upon this technical Bill, the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust (Boundaries) Bill 1985, for the purpose of belabouring an issue which clearly does not enjoy majority support either in the Northern Territory or, for that matter, in Australia. The Bill is designed to do no more than make a minor variation of the description of the boundaries of land granted to the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Opposition that during that period the legislation enjoyed the support of the Opposition. At that stage it was sympathetic to the rights of Aborigines in Australia. We can look back on that period and say that today the Opposition has an attitude different from the attitude it had when it was in government. Whilst it is conceded that part of the role of the Opposition is to oppose, there are certainly, and surely should be, areas which are common ground in respect of a whole range of issues, particularly our obligations to the Aboriginal people. Yet we see what can be described only as a cheap and nasty attempt to belittle the endeavours of the Government to accept what should be a national obligation to the indigenous people of our continent.

In effect the legislation deals with one section of the boundary, approximately nine kilometres long, which will be shifted some 220 metres north of its present location. This involves a total area of about two square kilometres. One would think we were dealing with an important country somewhere else in the world judging by the clamour and hysteria that have characterised the statements of Mr Tuxworth and the Opposition, in the House of Representatives and in this place, to this important area. The Opposition is taking advantage of a very important but minor piece of legislation in the sense that it seeks to vary in a very small way the land area that surrounds this project.

The Bill will also confirm the validity of the proclamation and the description of the Uluru National Park which was proclaimed in 1977, again a proclamation that was made during the Liberal-National Party coalition Administration. That again emphasises the point I made earlier about the inadequacy of the Opposition to take a positive position in respect of this issue and many other national issues. The debate on this Bill should be constrained and limited, given the technical and narrow objectives of the Bill. Yet that has been ignored in the debate. On the contrary, we have had attempts by the Opposition to rock the boat and take advantage of the misconceptions, prejudices and racism that exist in the community in order to score some cheap political point against the Government. That is to be deplored and rejected as I hope it will be when the Senate deals with this matter.

Of course the Senate is entitled to debate the pros and cons of granting title to the Aboriginal beneficiaries of the Petermann Land Trust which has already taken place. The Opposition has made its position known during not only this debate but also the previous debate. Its attitude to Aboriginal matters has changed markedly in recent times. One can presume only that that change has been part of a political ploy to gain favour amongst the prejudiced section of the community that unfortunately exists. The Opposition seems unprepared to limit the scope of the debate but seeks again to trot out the now discredited allegations that in some way Aborigines are about to deprive other Australian citizens of the enjoyment of the Uluru National Park and other arguments in blind support of the Northern Territory Government.

I interpose that even in the Northern Territory one has to say that the attitude being taken by the Chief Minister does not enjoy anywhere near the amount of support one would expect to find having regard to the stand he has taken and the exploitation of this issue by the Opposition parties in the House of Representatives and the Senate. It can be conceded that newspapers generally take an objective view, but certainly not necessarily a pro-Labor view, on matters. Nevertheless, one newspaper says:
The NT Government has misjudged public opinion on the Uluru National Park handover to Aborigines.
According to a mid-week Territory street poll, the government lacks support for boycotting the October 26th ceremony, to be attended by Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen.
Thirty people were asked: `Should the NT Government boycott the handover ceremony on October 26?'
Eleven people agreed with the boycott decision, but 19 said the government had made the wrong decision.
Many indicated they were normally Country-Liberal Party supporters.

It seems strange that the Opposition parties, who are always so vociferous about the important role that the monarchy plays through its representative in this country, should take the step of suggesting a boycott and causing embarrassment to the very important office of Governor-General and the very important person that Sir Ninian Stephen is. One would have thought that the attempts being made by the Northern Territory Government and the support that has been given to it in this place would be seen as an embarrassment and a negative attitude to take to that important office of Governor-General.

One can only say that this is cheap political point scoring, an attempt to whip up public opinion and to exploit prejudice and racism at the expense of Her Majesty's representative. That is to be deplored. Yet that seems to be the sole motivation of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Tuxworth, who lacks policy, credence and alternative proposals and seeks therefore to create division where division should not exist. Senators will know that Mr Tuxworth has been appearing on television. On one such appearance he was confronted with the indisputable fact that his predecessor, the former Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, who is now a member of the national Parliament, representing the Northern Territory, had supported the granting of title to the relevant Aboriginal groups. The Northern Territory Conservation Minister, Mr Hatton, had said that he has no objections to the granting of title to Aborigines and Mr Tuxworth himself had at that time offered support for the Everingham position. So we are entitled to ask the motivation of the Opposition. What is the motivation of the Northern Territory Government? It can only be described as despicable, unnecessary and disruptive. When he was asked why he had now changed his mind Mr Tuxworth suggested that there was now a matter of principle at stake, that principle being whether Ayers Rock and its surrounds should be controlled by the Commonwealth or the Northern Territory. What a specious and totally unacceptable argument, when we know that almost 20 years ago in a rarity of referendum decisions the Australian people decided that responsibility for all matters associated with Aborigines should rest with the Australian Government. I would have thought that the least we could have expected of the Liberal Party in this Parliament was that it would have respected that view of the Australian people and would have taken on board the essential prerequisite for that responsibility, which is a unified position between the Commonwealth and the States.

Of course, as that did not suit Mr Tuxworth's political position, he has launched an advertising campaign which would suggest something very different. That campaign improperly, mischievously and wrongly suggests that a small Aboriginal group is about to deprive the rest of Australia from the use and enjoyment of what is a national monument. I suggest that that is a matter of great regret. The Northern Territory Government has once again-as we have seen since the Hawke Government came to office-reverted to its most common tactic of attacking everything national, of kicking the Aboriginal can in order to drum up political support for its argument that the Commonwealth should have less power in running Uluru National Park. Not only is that view shared by what I would hope to be the majority of Australians, but the Northern Territory News also said in a recent editorial:
Chief Minister, Mr Ian Tuxworth's $200,000 publicity extravaganza over the Ayers Rock hand-over is a waste of public money.

Mr Tuxworth left yesterday on a crusade to make the Australian public aware of the injustice of the Federal Government's decision to give Commonwealth title of Ayers Rock to the Aboriginal traditional owners.
I recall that once, several years ago, there was common ground in the Parliament on this issue. The editorial went on to say:
Like most crusades based on missionary zeal, it is pointless. He well knows his chances of making any changes to the ceremony planned for October 26, less than three weeks away, are zero.
Not only do we have that view-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I hesitate to interrupt the Minister, but the fact that he is speaking in inflammatory terms about a most delicate subject is worth mentioning. However, it is beside the point the order that I wish to raise. The Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust (Boundaries) Bill 1985, which is before the Senate, is not about the handing over of Uluru to the Aboriginal people. It is a Bill that concerns a very small matter. It is to clear up a discrepancy that has been discovered relating to a block of land about nine kilometres long and 200 metres wide. That is all the Bill is about. If you intended to allow the Minister to encroach into a very inflammatory and delicate matter-and he is entitled to do that-you will have it on your head because other people, particularly those on the Liberal side who feel equally strongly and equally genuinely about this matter, will become just as inflammatory. With great respect, I warn you of the dangers that are inherent in your allowing the Minister to proceed on this course.
—I must admit that it is the first time as occupant of the chair I have received a warning. I do not see any point of order and I ask Senator Gietzelt to continue.

—The debate has ranged over a wide area and I was seeking to respond to what has been the objective nature of this debate conducted both in the Parliament and in the public arena. I have been attempting to suggest that these tactics may have some impact on certain elements within the Northern Territory community. They will not have the desired effect on the vast majority of thinking Australians because they already know that similar arrangements exist for the Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory. That is one of the great national parks of the world and it has been successfully administered and run as a national park, notwithstanding that much of the land on which it is situated is owned by the Aborigines. The title to that land was handed over by the Fraser Government in 1978. Kakadu has been operating as a national park and the public has not been denied access to it. The present Opposition parties have never suggested that these arrangements should be overturned. Thus one wonders why we are being subjected in the debates, both in the other place and in the Senate, to the principles that have been raised by the Opposition parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that Mr Tuxworth is seeking to generate is nothing more and nothing less than a regurgitation of the old Northern Territory versus the Commonwealth argument as to who should control the two major national parks in the Territory. The coalition administration under Malcolm Fraser did not concede the right of the Territory to take control of either Kakadu or Uluru. Nor does this Government. One would hope that we would have a common position in respect of that principle and that policy which has existed over time. What the Fraser Government appreciated and what the present Government knows is that the Northern Territory Government does not have the confidence of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. That Government has consistently opposed Aboriginal land claims, it has sought to frustrate the making of land claims and in a dozen other ways it has generated situations in which the Government and Aboriginal citizens of the Northern Territory are in confrontation. These actions do not give rise to the sort of confidence that Aboriginal people must have if they are to be encouraged to co-operate with and seek the participation of the Northern Territory Government in areas that affect Aboriginal affairs. Of course, this Government wants co-operation; it does not seek confrontation with the Northern Territory Government. We seek co-operation not only with the Northern Territory Government, but also with all other State Governments where there is a need to achieve common aims. I recall the debates that have taken place over many years, when present shadow Ministers were in government. I was pleased and prepared to give support-and did so-to the common view that they expressed in those times, particularly when they had responsibilities for Aboriginal affairs, and I thought that we had achieved a much more common position than has been expressed in debate on this matter.

The Government, of course, opposes the proposals put forward by the Senate Opposition and asks the Senate to agree to the legislation and reject the amendment to the second reading motion moved by the Opposition. To that extent we hope that we will move back to a more rational position, a position where we will not have differences of interpretation, differences of objectives and differences that I think only harm the cause of the Aboriginal people in our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I proceed I would like to go back to the point of order that I received about five or 10 minutes ago when the Chair was warned. I think it is most inappropriate for an honourable senator to warn the Chair. I ask that that type of point of order not be raised again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak for a few moments on this Bill because we are all interested in it and in the welfare of the Aboriginal people of Australia. I think it was quite appropriate that Senator Chipp should have drawn attention to the rather inflammatory remarks made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) because there is no need for that. It could conceivably inspire people on this side of the chamber, who are equally concerned about the subject before the Chair, to engage in similar tactics which I think are unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with an important issue and the Opposition I think has quite properly drawn attention to the fact that the Northern Territory Government was not consulted. I think that is uncalled for. Had the Northern Territory Government been consulted the Government may have modified its attitude to the question of this national monument which is part of our national heritage. Sometimes we lose sight of the fact that in Australia today something like 159,000 people claim to be Aborigines. Of that number, probably 35,000 to 50,000-it is pretty difficult to put a figure on it-could be regarded as traditional tribal Aborigines. With respect to this Bill I understand that of the order of 200 traditional owners have been identified. I just make that point because this area is of great significance and interest not only to the Aboriginal people but also to the 15 million other Australians who regard it as part of our national heritage. In particular, those people who have lived in the Northern Territory all their lives, probably fourth or fifth generation Australians, also should have been regarded as a little more important than the Government has chosen to regard them.

I would like to refer to Senator Kilgariff, who is unable to be here due to an unfortunate accident he had earlier in the week. As he has taken a great interest in this matter, I draw attention to some comments he made as recently as 9 October. He referred to a claim by Mr Clyde Holding, the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that Ayers Rock would remain accessible to all Australians after its handover to the Mutitjulu Aboriginal community. He claims that that is very misleading and simply does not stand up to an examination of the facts. Senator Kilgariff referred to an incident on 28 September when Mr Irwin Chlanda, of Chlanda Pty Ltd Television and News Services in Alice Springs, was requested by a ranger of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to leave the precincts of Uluru National Park.

Senator Kilgariff pointed out that, prior to this incident, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Professor Ovington, had stated that only those persons involved in filming for the purposes of producing entertainment or dramatic features need apply for a permit to film and that filming for news or documentary purposes did not require a permit. Senator Kilgariff went on to comment that on 28 September Mr Chlanda informed rangers of both the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Northern Territory Conservation Commission that he intended to undertake filming for news purposes. He informed the rangers out of courtesy, as under Professor Ovington's guidelines he was not required to inform anyone.

Later that day Mr Chlanda was approached by Mr Hicks of the ANPWS who said that in his judgment Mr Chlanda was filming a commercial and should therefore stop filming and leave the park. I think Senator Kilgariff was quite justified in making that comment publicly, as he did in a Press release yesterday. He ended by saying:
. . . this was just another example of an increasingly common complaint from persons wishing to film within the park.
If this attitude is supposed to reflect Mr Holding's assurances on the continued accessibility of the Park, it does not augur well for the future.

Those are the sorts of things that would concern everybody on this side of the House and that is the reason we drew attention to the fact that the Northern Territory Government was not appropriately consulted and that these rules and regulations concerning the filming of news items such as were referred to in Senator Kilgariff's comments could not have been clearly understood by everybody. It is clear from the statement he made that Mr Hicks of the ANPWS was obviously uninformed.

Certainly the referendum to which the Minister referred not only gave Aborigines an entitlement to be enrolled and to vote but also gave the Commonwealth powers to introduce legislation for their benefit. There is no dispute about that, but when we are dealing with sensitive Federal-State matters in this regard and with a national monument which is of interest to 15 million Australians as well as 159,000 people who claim to be Aborigines, I think it is incumbent on the Government to consult carefully and closely with the Northern Territory Government or any other Government where the Federal Government seeks to intrude its powers in relation to national parks of this character. I think it is very sensible and appropriate for the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and the Opposition generally to support this amendment to decline to give this Bill a second reading because of its concern that the Northern Territory Government was not consulted in relation to alterations to the boundaries of the Petermann Land Trust or its effect in the Uluru National Park at any stage prior to the introduction of this Bill into the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to participate in this debate as the Bill is in the hands of my colleague Senator Peter Baume, but as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who is at the table, gave me an honourable or a dishonourable mention-I am not sure which-I thought I would respond and put a view on the amendment which the Opposition is putting forward. We are suggesting that this Bill not be given a second reading because of our concern that the Northern Territory Government was not consulted at any stage prior to the introduction of the Bill into Parliament in relation to the alteration of the boundaries of the land trust or its effect on the Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park. We are concerned about the importance of consultation in this area. I wish to place that concern in a slightly wider context so that the Minister who is at the table will quite understand the position which I adopt and which, I think, fairly reflects the position of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The present situation of Aboriginal people in Australia can give rise to very little satisfaction. It seems to me that in terms of the level of public support which can be expected or which has been received by the Aboriginal people, we are going through a period of steep decline. The unfortunate fact of the matter is that there is a high degree of impatience in the community with some of the demands which have been made in the recent past by representatives of the Aboriginal community. These demands are squarely in line with the pre-election promises of the present Government.

The Minister made a plea for a return to bipartisanship or to a common position, which is what applied in the mid-1970s. That is correct: there was a very high degree of bipartisanship in this Parliament in the period 1975 and 1976. I have picked two years; in one there was a Labor government and in the other there was a Liberal government. It is a fact that it was the Liberal Government which put the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act through this Parliament, with a high degree of bipartisan support.

It is important to remember that the legislation which we put through, in common with the legislation put forward by the Whitlam Labor Government, was federalist in its nature. It dealt with the position of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory and it did not purport to extend land rights on a national basis. As I recall it, the legislation was put forward on the basis that it might well provide a useful precedent for other parts of Australia. In fact, a State Liberal government in South Australia enacted legislation which has much in common with the Northern Territory legislation, with the very important distinction that the South Australian legislation did not give an unlimited right to claim land where that land was vacant and where Aboriginal traditional ownership could be proved; rather, in a move which, with the wisdom of hindsight, I now see as having been very sound, the South Australian Government in its two pieces of legislation, defined the extent of land which would be affected.

Going back through the history of the land rights legislation, what the Liberal Government predicted in 1976 would be the impact of that legislation was really inaccurate. We predicted that a certain proportion of the Northern Territory was likely to be claimed. We underestimated the extent of the claims. As I understand it, the reality is that virtually all of the land which was available to be claimed has been claimed, and a substantial proportion of the Northern Territory stands to become Aboriginal land-more than was predicted by Mr Viner on behalf of the Government in these early days.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is presuming the Land Commissioner and the Minister make--

—Of course. All I am saying is that things have worked out slightly differently from what was predicted. Another item I draw attention to is the fact that in those early years of the land rights legislation, as was predicted by Mr Justice Woodward, certain difficulties emerged. It was novel legislation and difficulties emerged which had not been anticipated. Mr Justice Woodward suggested in his second report that we would need to review the legislation after a few years of its being in operation and be prepared to amend it in the light of experience. It was my fairly unhappy experience and, I think, the unhappy experience of my successors Senator Peter Baume and Mr Wilson-
—Order! Senator Vigor, would you either go into the gallery or stay out?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. For many years it has been the custom in this place, and I would have thought you would have caught up with it, that members of the Liberal Party and members of the Labor Party freely converse with their advisers outside the chamber. With the agreement of the President of the Senate, four years ago I made similar arrangements for the Australian Democrats to do exactly the same thing in that part of the chamber behind me which is not the public gallery. That is the Democrats' advisers box. I am amazed that you would make such a ruling and embarrass one of my colleagues. I will take this up with the President unless you rule differently now; that it is our right to converse, to receive from and give papers to our advisers in the advisers box in the same way as it is the right of the Liberal Party or the Labor Party to do that with their advisers.

—I take your comment, Senator Chipp. I was asking Senator Vigor not to lean over the Bar. It is my understanding that it has not been acceptable behaviour to lean over the Bar. He should either go into that part of the gallery, which you rightly say has been set aside for the Australian Democrats--
—By the President.

—I am not arguing with that, Senator Chipp; I am saying that as far as I am concerned it is not acceptable behaviour to lean over the Bar. It is much better for the senator involved to go into the area where the advisers are. I will not rule otherwise. If you wish to take the matter up with the President that is your prerogative.
—I certainly will. It is intolerable.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not wish to address you on the point of order. I shall resume my speech. I was pointing out that it was my unhappy experience, and that of my successors as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that trying to obtain amendments which I thought might have appeared necessary given difficulties in the Act, proved very difficult. There was a very unco-operative attitude on the part of the then Opposition-the Labor Party- to amending the Act. We entered into what seemed to be almost endless rounds of discussion with the various land councils. We did not succeed in removing some of the difficulties which emerged with respect to the administration of that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the expression `land rights' is, in my view, now quite a counterproductive one from the point of view of the Aboriginal people and most of the Australian community in part relates to the fact that we were unable to remove some of the difficulties from the Northern Territory legislation. As an ex-Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I regret my failure to do so. I think that my successors also regret that. As the Opposition indicated in its policy before the last election, it is committed to making amendments to the Northern Territory legislation to remove some of those difficulties.

In my view, the real difficulty that has arisen is that the Labor Party post-1976 chose to move away from the bipartisan position which was very firmly rooted in the political administrative and legal realities within which we were working. When the Labor Party opted to go from having a fundamentally federalist approach, certainly with respect to land matters, to promising the Aboriginal people national land rights legislation, I believe a significant error was made. We are currently living with the results of that error.

As I understand it, it remains Federal Labor policy to enact Federal land rights legislation. On examination of the proposal, I say that that would be a very difficult thing to do. It would be a very difficult policy to effect. I am confident that it would cause enormous difficulty. Constitutional, legal and administrative challenges would be mounted against it. My conclusion is that it is not a practical or feasible policy. In any event, in my view, that policy represents a very important element in the continuing difficult and very destructive debate which is still going on in Australia. The reality is that States, both Labor and Liberal, would stoutly resist the imposition of the Federal Labor policy. It is my belief that there is no real prospect of the Government introducing national land rights legislation. But the unfortunate fact is that while the possibility remains alive, the debate remains alive and the difficulties continue. I think that the Aboriginal people are going backwards as a result.

What I have said is not something that I have not said before. I wish to incorporate in Hansard about 700 to 800 words I wrote which were published in the Australian newspaper on 24 May 1985 in the form of an open letter to Mr Hawke. I sought a return to bipartisanship by the Government and the Opposition. I make that request because I regard the current difficulties with great seriousness. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
AN OPEN LETTER TO MR HAWKE
COMMENT:
SENATOR FRED CHANEY
I am pleased that you, Prime Minister, finally agreed to see a delegation of Aborigines on the difficult question of land rights.

I very much regret that subsequent to the visit there has been further reporting of confusion about the Government's intentions and objectives in this very sensitive area. If it is true that the Government is going to postpone its decision-making for yet another year in favour of further consultation, then I urge you to rethink your position as soon as possible.

The last thing Aborigines and other Australians need is another year of doubt and another year of strident argument among the disparate interest groups who are concerned at what your Government might do.

You are very remote from the Australian community if you do not understand what harm that is doing to Aboriginal people and to race relations in Australia. It is my own assessment that your Government will eventually do little or nothing in this area.

The opposition to national legislation is widespread and reaches across the political spectrum. The path of national legislation is strewn with obstacles, constitutional and legal difficulties, administrative nightmares and enormous cost.

The end result is likely to be no action or token action and while it is difficult for you to climb down from the bold promises made in opposition and repeated in feebler form since assuming government, it is far better to sort the position out now than to continue this uncertainty.

The widely varying arrangements made in the different States for dealing with the land needs of Aboriginal people do give rise to some uneven treatment across State boundaries. The differences, however, also reflect the widely varied circumstances of the Aboriginal people.
To impose a uniform Commonwealth approach is unlikely to be successful in any sense.
Inflame

Nor can you avoid facing up to the very real difficulties which exist in the Northern Territory. In the years following the enactment of the Territory legislation by the Fraser Government, difficulties emerged. That was not surprising. The legislation was novel and the Woodward report suggested review would be necessary in light of practical experience.

Successive Liberal ministers for Aboriginal affairs in the Fraser Government sought agreement for changes to the Northern Territory Land Rights Act to remove some of the difficulties which have tended to inflame the public attitude against land rights.

A major obstacle to our achieving that objective was the obduracy of your party in opposing change and its announced determination to extend land rights on the Northern Territory model Australia-wide.

No one in your Government would seriously advance that proposition today. Again, it is in the long-term interests of everyone, including Aboriginal Australians, that the Northern Territory legislation be revised to remove some of the obvious problems which have damaged the fabric of race relations and greatly reduced public support for Aboriginal policies generally.

No one comes to this debate who has not a history of mistakes. But you are in government now and your maintenance of mistaken stances does great harm. Now is the time to re-write Aboriginal affairs policy to set achievable and realistic goals so that we can resume positive work in an area that has become far too negative. At a minimum the Government should make it clear that it will not pursue national land rights legislation and that it will work in co-operation with the States to meet the reasonable aspirations of Aboriginal Australians. Decisions in this regard are now urgent. If you fail to declare your position we can expect:
CONTINUED opposition by the States to possible national legislation.
CONTINUED agitation by the mining industry.
CONTINUED agitation by some Aboriginals and their supporters.

Total reconciliation of these viewpoints is not possible. What will satisfy the States will not meet the Labor platform and policy. What will satisfy the miners will never satisfy the Aboriginal land councils. What will satisfy the land councils will not satisfy most non-Aboriginal Australians. But it is possible to reduce tension if you give a realistic lead. You must set achievable objectives and you must achieve them. The past two years have been a damaging farce. Please do not prolong it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is really in that context that one has to examine the transfer of Ayers Rock. Ayers Rock is a national symbol as well as a site of significance to Aboriginal Australians, a point made by previous speakers on behalf of the Opposition. It is, in my view, in the current state of debate in Australia quite inflammatory to be going about this in the way that the Government has done. I have met with some of the people who were claimants of this land in the original hearing before Mr Justice Toohey. I respect their position. I think that the move which was made by the Government to acknowledge Aboriginal title and to obtain a lease back has, in fact, been taken at a very difficult time which makes it a very unwise step for the Government to take.

SPEECH.PARA: I have earlier expressed the view in this place that the Australian community is unlikely to understand and certainly unlikely to agree with a rental payment being made to the Aboriginal people. I think that the Aboriginal majority on the board which I understand is being provided is also a mistake. The failure of the Government to be sensitive to the feelings of the broader Australian community and to the ease with which that community is turning against the Aboriginal community and away from its interests should receive much greater consideration.

I do not for a moment suggest that the Government should not pay close regard to the needs of Aboriginal people. I had a number of days in the central reserve last week. Revisiting places such as Warburton, Jamieson, Blackstone and Waraburna is a salutary reminder of the very significant and difficult tasks which lie ahead of us. I believe that this Government is successfully dividing the Australian people on this issue. We have gone from a position where there was massive public support for Commonwealth involvement in Aboriginal affairs in the mid-1960s when the referendum was passed to a stage where it has become a political millstone around the neck of the Government. What is more important, it has become a destructive element in the propositions that we would all support, namely, that the position of the Aboriginal people needs to be improved and advanced.

This is a small example. The failure to consult with the Northern Territory Government is a failure to acknowledge the concerns that exist in the rest of the community. To fail to consult in those circumstances is to provide a further cause of alarm, unrest, disputation, argument, unhappiness and resentment. This Government is doing the worst possible job, with whatever motives, in handling this difficult and sensitive portfolio. I regret to say it, but I believe that in a party which has many people who are deeply concerned about Aboriginal affairs we have a Minister who is totally insensitive to what is happening in the community and the contribution that he is making to reducing the situation of Aboriginal people in Australia. If this Government has any sense at all it will revert to a federalist approach in Aboriginal affairs and it will put into the position of Minister for Aboriginal Affairs somebody who has some regard for getting a return to public support for doing something about the serious problems that Aboriginal people face. This is symbolism of the worst sort. This is a symbolic gesture which may give people a warm glow when they are out there making big fellows of themselves in the presence of a few hundred Aboriginal people who, I am sure, will be very pleased.

In terms of the total job which is to be done this is a very thoroughly destructive exercise and it is typical of too much of what this Government has done in this area. I agree with the spirit in which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) made his comments in terms of the desirability of having a bipartisan position. I think that would be a great step forward for Aboriginal affairs. But I say to him very seriously that until the Labor Party acknowledges the reality which is, in fact, governing its actions at the moment, that the States have a very significant role in all this, a role which cannot and must not be taken from them, we cannot get back to the level of agreement that both he and I think should exist.

I wished to take part in this debate because in a period in Australia where, perhaps, more attention is being paid to issues of taxation, the vexed issue of returning to a higher level of employment and all those issues which are burdening the broader Australian community, inadequate parliamentary time and thought is being given to an issue which has bedevilled us for generations and which will go on bedevilling us for many more. I think it is time for the Government to think again about its approach to Aboriginal affairs. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who is at the table and who is a man of goodwill in these matters to think about whether the approach of his Party is correct. I think it is fatally wrong and it is doing enormous damage to the Aboriginal people.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
