SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Boundaries of the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no need to rehash the arguments which I advanced during the second reading debate. The Opposition believes that clause 3 should be opposed and we will oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported; report adopted without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gietzelt) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition sought to amend the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust (Boundaries) Bill in the Committee stage by removing clause 3. As I indicated during the second reading debate, having failed in that, the Opposition will oppose the third reading.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill, to amend the Export Market Development Grants Act, contains a number of quite significant changes to that legislation. The legislation is part of the Government's May economic statement which had the objectives of expenditure restraint. As I have said already in another debate this morning, the Opposition does not oppose that and in fact welcomes the approach of the Government to economic expenditure restraint. Nevertheless, I want to make it clear that each government makes its own determinations of priorities in this regard, but that does not mean that the Opposition supports or does not oppose the particular priorities chosen by the Government. In our view the Government has been elected to govern and it makes its priorities in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we welcome and support the overall objective, that is not to be taken as an indication that we support each and every one of the Government's proposals. The May economic statement was a package of proposals. We are not in the business of remaking the Government package; therefore we are not opposing this measure, although we have a number of difficulties with it and would have moved in a different way in some respects.

The Opposition has, both in government and since it has been in opposition, a sympathy with, and a practical commitment to, export incentives. Certainly we support initiatives designed to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of the export market development grants scheme. In the debate in another place we have suggested several changes to the amendments that have been proposed to the scheme by the Government. Those changes have been particularised in the debate in the other place by my colleague who spoke on behalf of the Opposition. Certainly we want to see more encouragement given to Australian exporters. In particular, the Opposition is concerned that in this legislation the Government has not provided sufficient notice and consultation with exporters. It introduced the legislative changes only six days after announcing the proposals.

The Opposition is concerned also that difficulty will be caused for most businesses in finalising their accounts by terminating aspects of the scheme on 19 May and creating a broken period separate from the remainder of the financial year. We are concerned also at the failure of the Government to recognise commitments under the original scheme to provide grants on the original basis up to 30 June 1987. Despite those commitments, in respect of a number of exporters who otherwise looked forward to receiving grants up to 30 June 1987, the scheme will cease to do so from the cut off date of 19 May 1985. The Opposition is also concerned that this legislation fails to recognise the role of small business, which would clearly be disadvantaged in competing for grants under the revised arrangements provided for in this legislation. In order to give expression to those concerns I, on behalf of the Opposition, move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for-
(a) its lack of notice to and consultations with exporters in bringing in the legislation and making it effective 6 days after the announcement;
(b) its failure to recognise the commitment of the original scheme to provide grants on the original basis to 30 June 1987;
(c) the uncertainty caused by dividing a year into parts and not recognising the normal year ending at 30 June; and
(d) its lack of understanding in disadvantaging small business from competing for grants.

I register our strong opposition to clause 10 of the Bill, which gives the Minister the power to make a determination in writing, published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, declaring the Republic of South Africa to have been, with effect from 19 August 1985, a proscribed country. It spells out in detail what provisions may be included in such determinations. Policy in relation to sanctions being imposed on South Africa has already been the subject of considerable public debate, both in this chamber and elsewhere, by colleagues of mine. I reiterate that the Opposition does not believe that trade sanctions are in general appropriate and we do not believe that a provision of this kind should be included in the Bill. We will not support any determination made by the Minister in the exercise of the powers contained in this legislation.

The Opposition has received many representations from industry expressing widespread concern about the adverse impact on them, particularly on small business, as a result of the proposed amendments to the export market development scheme which are contained in this Bill. Unfortunately the Government does not seem to have registered such a level of concern nor has it been responsive to this level of criticism. We believe it would be most unfortunate and against the national interest if export industries were left to languish until the Opposition is returned to government and meets these concerns. We have an overwhelming commitment to the expansion of trade and an understanding of the importance of exports for Australia. I give the Government its due as I am sure it also is concerned about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—I have acknowledgement from the Minister at the table that he shares that concern. I welcome that. Perhaps the debate is really about how best to achieve this. The Opposition registers its concern with the way the Government is going about that generally and particularly in relation to the matter that we have in hand this morning. The Ferris report, the report of the National Export Marketing Strategy Panel, resulted from a major study into Australia's export performance and the role of government in lifting that performance and an examination of a broad range of areas, including this scheme. Its finding is that the manufacturing and service sectors have been poor export performers. It notes that primary products, both agriculture and minerals, account for about 80 per cent of our export revenues. In this regard it is disappointing that the Government is moving to reduce the international competitiveness of these sectors by extending export controls and introducing new taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ferris report also notes that the maintenance and expansion of existing exports should continue to be a linchpin in export development policy; that is, building on existing strengths and reputations. It makes 65 recommendations which it considers are the minimum changes needed, including 14 changes to the export market development scheme. However, we should recognise-as does the Ferris report-that marketing and incentives can form only part of a wider export strategy. It is imperative that Australian exports be price competitive and that Australia be a reliable supplier-I emphasise that-as no amount of marketing incentives will overcome deficiencies in this area, particularly on the question of reliability. That is probably an area in which the Government has been most vulnerable in its policies because of the prices and incomes accord and its readiness to give in to union muscle. It is in that area of reliability where we have been--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would be the one to talk about that. Have a look at what happened in 1982.

—What about coal? I particularly have that in mind. I suggest the honourable senator also should have had it in mind, or his colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) should.
—You look at your own performance.

—We are looking at the Government's at the moment and it has not been too good not only on maintaining reliability but also in meeting solemn promises that were made in particular to Japan by the former Minister for Resources and Energy, particularly in relation to coal. As I have said, the way the accord has worked and the Government has been so partial to union pressures is very worrying, and it will continue to concern us and large sections of the community. The accord, which has involved increasing labour costs, higher inflation and delays in fully discounting wage increases for the effects of depreciation will certainly lead to second round inflationary effects and will further erode the possibility of increasing Australia's export performance. The Opposition has very clearly stated policies in relation to what should be done about these matters. I do not intend to repeat them now.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already indicated that the coalition will not oppose this Bill-because of its support for the principles of expenditure restrain and also, as I have said, because the Government has included this as part of its priorities in its program of financial restraint-although we are opposed to certain aspects of it. I have covered most of the points that we have in mind. If further matters arise during the Committee stage perhaps I will comment then, in particular in regard to the clause dealing with the power of the Minister over South Africa and some of the other deficiencies that arise in these proposals. As I have said, I do not propose to move any amendments to change the nature of these proposals because of the overall attitude we are adopting to this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that the changes made by this Bill to the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 will have the major effect of cutting by some $80m the amount the Australian Government is prepared to allocate to the promotion of Australian exports. I know that the report by the National Export Marketing Strategy Panel, the Ferris report, recommended changes to the scheme following its detailed investigation. The scheme has been abused. Claimants have been receiving grants despite having generated little or no export income. Some of the larger companies that have benefited from this scheme are subsidiaries of multinational companies which could use their own substantial funds in seeking contracts to open up export markets. It was necessary to make some changes to the scheme, yet I cannot but believe that the Government's primary aim in making these changes is to cut government expenditure. Indeed, it was part of the mini-Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The expenditure cut was proudly announced by the Government in the May economic statement. It must have sounded familiar to Australians who have been involved in the export industry. In 1983, following recommendations by the Fraser razor gang, the export expansion grant scheme was abolished. Like its Liberal predecessors, this Government has decided that it is politically acceptable in Australia to reduce assistance to our exporters. In the short run that is probably right. Exporters are unlikely to take to the streets to gain maximum publicity for their cause. Yet a closer examination of the world economy and of Australia's external economic problems makes it clear that Australia's future prosperity is very closely linked to the potential and the performance of our export industries.

World trade is increasingly threatened by moves towards protectionism. We are living in a time of massive unemployment, oversupply of commodities and shrinking markets. This is all due to sluggish economic growth and accumulated foreign borrowings. The European Economic Community subsidises its farmers to the point where they can sell agricultural products for less than Australian farmers who are very much more efficient producers. It has been estimated that the European Economic Community's agricultural trade policy is costing the Australian economy $950m per annum. In the United States of Australia, the overvalued United States dollar has generated a congressional clamour for protection. I am not comforted by the fact that President Reagan and his advisers are all that stand between that congressional protectionist sentiment and protectionist legislation which can lead us on to a depression. If the Unites States dollar remains overvalued, American politicians will seek to protect themselves by protecting American industries. Those who have unbounded faith in the American President and Congress resisting protectionism should read Time magazine of 7 October this year, which states:

As the bill moved through Congress, formal protests from foreign countries flooded into Washington, eventually adding up to 200 pages. Both houses voted aye nonetheless. While the legislation sat on the President's desk, 1,028 American economists called for a veto. Herbert Hoover made it the law of the land anyway, swallowing his own reservations and, on June 17, signing the Tariff Act of 1930.

Known as Smoot-Hawley after its legislative sponsors, the bill promptly fulfilled the worst fears of critics. A new panic seized the already battered stock market; the slide continued for two years. In raising import duties on scores of items, in some cases to 50 per cent, the measure provoked angry retaliation by 25 of the nation's trading partners. US exports fell by nearly two-thirds in just two years.

We were in a depression. That is the type of situation we are faced with. Yet our Government is ignoring it. The United States Government has already introduced the farm export bonus scheme. Under this scheme countries which agree to buy agricultural produce from the United States will receive bonus tonnages on top of the amounts they contract to buy and pay for. The sum of $2 billion has been earmarked for this over the next three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to incorp- orate that?

—I was quoting the article. Therefore, while the EEC and the United States of America are increasing subsidies to their exporters, the Australian Government congratulates itself on cutting $80m off the export assistance grants. This brief world trade background sets the scene for a closer examination of Australia's external economic problems. Despite the devaluation, there is no evidence that our current account can be moved from its heavy deficit. While we still wait for devaluation to show its benefits in our balance of trade, our current account deficit widens. Our invisible payments burgeon as we meet repayments of interest on our accumulated foreign debt. Interest rates in Australia skyrocket in order to attract the foreign funds needed to balance the current account. In effect Australia's homebuyers are paying for the reckless foreign borrowing encouraged by this Government and its predecessors. Australia's real interest rates are amongst the highest in the world, yet still the current account deficit widens and our dollar sinks lower in value.

SPEECH.PARA: The devaluation is helping our exports, but our external problem is so chronic that it is only a short-sighted, false economy for a government effectively to reduce assistance to our export sector. Between 1973 and 1983 Australia's share of the total value of world trade fell by about 30 per cent. While world exports rose by 12 per cent, Australia's exports rose by only 8 per cent. In that time the value of our exports fell in 48 out of 65 of our main markets. I do not blame this Government for those figures. This Government is not responsible for the current state of the world economy or for the inefficiencies that protectionism has built into our manufacturing sector. However, it can do something to protect our exports against the effects of this type of attitude-indeed, to protect us against the common agricultural policy of the EEC and the massive invisible drain caused by past foreign borrowings.

I understand that we cannot change any of these situations overnight. However, it seems obvious that we should be doing everything to encourage and assist Australian enterprises in maintaining our export markets and also in creating new markets. We cannot afford to lose our export markets to countries that are prepared to subsidise their export industries, otherwise our trade deficit will continue to grow and our foreign debt will continue to grow even more as we make more and more foreign borrowings. We will need more money to pay back our past borrowing commitments and our currency will continue to weaken. Interest rates will remain high and living standards in Australia will continue to fall. If increasing our exports requires greater government assistance, governments must be prepared to allocate funds to subsidise exports. A surge in exports will reduce our current account deficit, create jobs, put confidence back into our dollar and reduce our dependence on foreign borrowings.

It is in this climate that the Bill, with its amendments to the export market development grant scheme, has been introduced. What do these amendments do? They cut $80m off our aid to exporters, and in a very rough and blunt way. I wish to go through the salient points of the amendments that are being made to the Act. The maximum grant entitlement for any one person remains at $200,000 per year. New claimants have a two-year no-export period of grace meaning that they can expend the money to develop the market without actually having the exports. This, in fact, departs from the recommendations of the Ferris report which recommended $300,000, that is a higher level of grant entitlement, and no period of grace. After the period of grace expires for the remaining five years of the scheme's applicability, maximum grants received will be the lesser of the $200,000 and a percentage of export earnings which are calculated on a sliding scale. We have no objection to that particular aspect of the Bill.

Grants will not be payable to firms with export earnings of more than $20m. This will discriminate against exporters of capital machinery. There is no carry over or averaging of export earnings and therefore there is positive disincentive for large exporters or exporters in the $20m region to increase their export earnings beyond the cut-off threshold for grants. In fact, we will introduce an amendment during the Committee stage of the Bill to make certain that exporters whose exports are still expanding will be able to continue to gain advantages from the export market development grants. I will say more about that in the Committee stage.

The tourist incentives have been excised from the EMDG legislation and a separate tourist overseas promotion scheme, TOPS, has been established administratively. This scheme resembles the scheme that we are trying to introduce for small exporters. It is a pre-declaration scheme in which the expenditure against which a grant can be obtained must be declared before the claim can be made. Under the changes there is a very unreasonable cut off for small exporters. The grants will be paid only where expenditure eligible for grants exceeds $5,000. This means that people who are investigating a market and starting off in the area will get no help at all under the current scheme. This provision very effectively excludes from government help all small businesses that are just starting to get under way.

We support the proposals of the Ferris report for a new exporters grant. Ferris suggests that $3m should be set aside for a scheme to help new exporters. We will move amendments in the Committee stage to introduce such a scheme, which I believe will address a notable problem. We will also oppose the $5,000 cut-off point on the grant because we believe that this is deleterious to the small exporter. Proposed new section 38 has been introduced to curb abuses and prevent manipulation of the scheme. The net in this area is cast far too widely, but if the scheme is administered with reasonable sensitivity by the Department, this section gives it the teeth to be able to exclude people who are using the scheme for overseas travelling junkets or personal benefit rather than effectively carrying on an export business. As such, we will not seek to amend that area.

The amendments that the Government is making to the Act will allow it to stop grants to any exporter who has markets in a country which has fallen from favour. Originally, this was a very general clause but as a result of discussions between ourselves, the Liberal Party, the Government and the Department of Trade, it has been narrowed down to the case of South Africa. I applaud the fact that it has been narrowed down to South Africa because we deplore the political situation that exists there. We will not move any changes to the Government's proposals in this respect.

The transitional provisions in the proposed legislation will cause a great number of anomalies and difficulties and may result in many exporters who have contracts over the transitional period being put into some difficulty. One reason for this is the fact that the scheme was introduced with only six days warning-as Senator Durack has said-and it has cut the financial year into two very strange segments-up to 19 May and from 19 May to 30 June. However, I am told by the Department of Trade personnel that this will result in a saving of $20m. Although we do not approve of this arrangement, in line with the Government's need to restrict expenditure and recognising that a number of rorts within the scheme needed to be handled immediately, we will not move any amendment to these dates. We will also not support the Opposition's addition to the second reading, because the question of dates is the main content of that particular amendment.

I wish to say something about the problems that will be caused and the reasons why we will move certain amendments during the Committee stage. Before that, I want to get some idea, which I have not been able to get so far, of the actual surveys that were made by the Department-I am sure that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) will have the details-to determine the number of rorts that were being carried out under the scheme. The evidence that we have been getting from the vast numbers of people who have written to us is that the surveys were conducted in a haphazard way. I would like to know how these surveys were conducted, how many claimants were contacted and what the term `non-exporter' means in the context of the survey. It is important to note that in the survey results it was stated that there were a number of drop-outs. In my understanding the drop-outs included rearrangements of corporate structure, such as a sole trader becoming a partnership or a company or some other recombination of groups in the course of action; a business undertaking being suddenly purchased by another entity and being incorporated into that entity; or possibly name changes. I understand that a number of the cases where businesses have disappeared have resulted from name changes. It seems we have not been able to get hard, factual evidence of the drop-out rate under the scheme and I would certainly like to know how many prosecutions have been launched for fraudulent abuse of the scheme.

The Government has justified its side of the argument by saying that the escalating costs of the scheme were getting out of hand. This is in fact a structural fault of the scheme. The scheme is not targeted to a product, to a market or to a product-market combination. If it were it would be much easier to control. It is an open-ended invitation for people who are involved in the export market to get support. There has been no change to that aspect of the scheme and it will still be regarded as a production subsidy instead of as a scheme for export incentives. Admittedly there is a sliding scale which encourages people to increase their exports in order to maintain the level of grants. As I said before, this is something that we support. However, I am not convinced that the percentages in that scheme are the best for the export industries.

I turn now to the problems that will accompany the scheme and give honourable senators some idea of how the amendments which we have proposed will attack those problems. I understand that we will not be supported in this by the Liberals who are basically saying: `Look, it is the Government's problem. It is a money Bill. We are not going to do anything about it'. The proposal that I put to the Opposition was that I would divide my amendments, and I will be doing so. I will be dividing my amendments into two groups-one which costs nothing and which improves the scheme, and the other which will cost money and will correct the problem for small exporters. This will give the Liberal Party a chance of reviewing its activity. I understand that the Liberals' reason for not voting for the amendments is that they would be changing the Government's revenue-raising capacity. The amendments which do not change the total revenue that the Government requires will be moved separately. The only one which costs money is amendment No. 2.

We believe that the export grants should have been continued in their current form until 1988, which was what the Government promised. It is very difficult for people to exist in an environment of continually-changing laws and continually-changing rules in the community. The Government puts an enormous strain on business by continually changing the ground rules under which it operates. This is one thing that we deplore.

I have received letters from a number of people, including one from the Australian Chambers of Commerce Export Council, which supports the type of views I have put forward. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Australian Chambers of Commerce Export Council which sets out its view, a concerted view, on what should have been done with the legislation.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
THE AUSTRALIAN CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE EXPORT COUNCIL
PO Box 63, Caulfied South, Victoria 3162
Telephone: Office (03) 211 1088
Telex AA31561 PEFRA
PF/cs...17 July 1985
Senator David Vigor,
10 Pitt Street,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
My dear Senator,
I am writing to you again as Chairman of the Australian Chamber of Commerce Export Council and aware that you are the spokesman for Trade for the Australian Democrats in the Senate.

I felt that it would be appropriate to inform you of the views of exporters with reference to changes that the Government has already announced and which will be debated very early in the Budget Session. Briefly the situation is as follows:
The Minister for Trade has announced changes to the Export Development Grants Act. These changes mainly refer to the first $5,000.00 of expense not being grantable.
The maximum remain at $200,000.00 however.
The Grant to be phased out when a company exports 20 million dollars.
The Grant year is to be changed for this particular period to finish for 1984-85 on the 20th of May, and then run from the 20th of May to 30th June 1986.
The Grant percentage however of 70 per cent has remained with some qualifications which reduces the Grant if the exporter wishes to travel first class instead of business class on overseas trips.

The National Export Committee of which I am Deputy Chairman, and which represents the majority of exporters in Australia through their national organisations has decided unanimously to support the Minister and again with his commitment however that the legislation would be put through the House as quickly as possible. The Minister has agreed to introduce the changes in the House in the first week of the Budget session and endeavour to have it passed by the House at maximum speed for it then to be debated in the Senate and the changes then to become effective.
The reasons for the agreement by the National Export Committee were quite clear.
(1) There is a commitment by the Government to maintain the Grant for five years and that there will be no further changes.

(2) The need to accept the fact that Australia is undergoing certain budgetary restraints and while they should not be placed upon exporters at this present time the changes were felt to be reasonable with one exception which we will refer to.

(3) The absolute need for the legislation to be passed quickly so that exporters awaiting their grants for the 1984-85 year can make their claims forthwith and receive their payments as quickly as possible. This is especially important to small and medium sized firms.

The Minister was asked to agree that the claims forms however would be available before the introduction of the Bill in the House so as to avoid any further delays to which he has agreed and I am now advised that the forms will be available on the 22nd of July. The Minister also agreed and has in the meantime made adequate arrangements that funds be placed at the disposal of the Grants Board to pay as quickly as practicable any outstanding and overdue amounts. Fifty-four million dollars have been transferred to the Grants Board for that effect.
The Minister has also agreed, and I am advised that this has been done that further staff be placed at the disposal of the Grants Board to process applications at a much quicker rate than before.

For all those reasons the National Export Committee has agreed to support the Minister. The one question that arose was the limit of 20 million dollars because of the reduction of the Australian dollar in its value against the American dollar only represents approximately US$12 million, which may be too small a threshold, even for small or medium sized companies.

Nevertheless agreement has been reached with the Minister that the 20 million may remain subject to further discussion during the Grant year and the Minister has accepted that if the proposals are made to him and reasons given to him to change the amount are reasonable and in the interest of the National Economy he will be flexible in his approach.

It is our feeling therefore that the Minister has complied with all the arrangements made with him. We have as a body expressed confidence that if the need arises for further discussion during the Grant year, because of the need for further incentives to exports he certainly could be available for substantial discussions in depth to review the decisions made and agreed to, always taking into account the over-riding national interest that our exports have to rise by a substantial percentage to overcome our current account deficit.
The other matter is the Australian Trading Commission with which we have agreed across the Board, and want to give it a chance to operate as planned by the Minister and his Department.

It is therefore important that both Bills be passed without delay. The Grants Bill should really go through all its stages, latest after the first two weeks recess after the first week of sitting. It would be enormously detrimental to small and medium sized businesses if any delay would result in deferment of payments.

Our organisation is confident that Mr Dawkins will adhere to all the arrangements as he has done so far, and we want to give him an opportunity to test out his views and we are furthermore totally confident that should the need arise he will prove to be flexible if proof can be given that the National interest will be served by further discussions and revisions of the legislation.
May I therefore respectfully request that the Australian Democrats support the Government in these two pieces of legislation and assist us at the same time of a speedy passage of both bills.
I am Deputy Chairman of the National Export Committee and therefore you can rest assured that the reflection of my views in this letter are totally in accordance with admiration of that body.

If you however wish to discuss the matter further with me or with the Chairman Mr Don Monro who resides in Melbourne, you can rest assured that either, or both of us will be available to you when you come to Melbourne next and we will be able to provide you with as much information as you may require so as to enable you to recommend to the Australian Democrats to give total support to those two groups.
I very much appreciate your interest in this matter and remain with kind personal regards.
Sincerely yours
PETER FRANKEL
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I also have a letter from a Mr Denver Davies of Grant-Aid Pty Ltd. In his letter he sets out admirably a number of specific cases which I have taken into account in proposing the amendments that we will put forward. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that letter from Grant-Aid Pty Ltd which contains cases which I believe will be of immense interest to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
GRANT-AID PTY LTD
Unit 214 ``West Point'',
396 Scarborough Beach Rd,
Osborne Park 6017
P.O. Box 57, Mt Hawthorn 6016
Telephone 444 0366
1 August 1985
DBD/PM
Senator David Vigor,
10 Pitt Street,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Dear David,
Thank you for affording us the opportunity of speaking to you on the proposed changes to the Export Market Development Grants Scheme.
During our discussions, you mentioned that you would like further information in respect of;
(i) The conventional wisdom that the EMDG Scheme has been widely abused, and
(ii) Some case histories on the effect of the proposed changes.
Page 31 of the January, 1985 Report of the National Export Marketing Strategy Panel (the Ferris Report) states,

``according to an evaluation recently completed by the Department of Trade, at a conservative estimate, 14 per cent of claimants were non-exporters and doubts existed about either the export performance or commitment to export of at least a further 5 per cent. Moreover, indications are that almost half of all claimants drop out of the scheme by the end of the third year. Evidence was also provided by other sources of some fraudulent abuse of the Scheme''.
The first page of the Minister for Trade's May 15 Press Release on Export Incentives contains the following statement;

``The Government's consideration took place in the light of the recommendations of the Report of the National Export Marketing Panel (the Ferris Report) and an evaluation of the scheme prepared by the Department of Trade.

The Department's evaluation, which was based on a random sample survey, disclosed major deficiencies in the scheme. Almost 50 per cent of claimants drop out of the E.M.D.G. Scheme after three grant years having generated little or no export sales. Significantly under the Scheme an export earnings test does not apply for the first three grant years but for their fourth grant year claimants must have export earnings of at least $25,000 or $10,000 in the case of claimants in respect of industrial property rights or know-how. Indeed, as the Ferris Report pointed out, it is possible under the scheme for a claimant to receive up to the maximum grant of $200,000 a year for three years without ever producing any export revenue.
This finding points to the fact that the scheme is either being aimlessly or frivously used, or being abused by a large number of claimants''.
Taken together, the above two statements lead the average person to believe the scheme is being ``ripped off'' to a very significant degree. I would dispute that assertion.
Management Consultants
Export Grants
Research Grants
Other Government Grants
As the Ferris Report preceded the Minister's Media Release, I assume that the Minister used that Report as the basis for his opinions. The points that he seems to have seized upon are;
(i) 14 percent of claimants were non-exporters and doubts existed about a further 5%.
(ii) Indications are that almost half of all claimants drop out of the scheme by the end of the third year; and
(iii) Evidence was also provided by other sources of some fraudulent abuse of the Scheme.
(i) It would appear that the Department of Trade random sample survey revealed the 14% and 5%. Questions that need answers in this respect are;
How was the survey conducted?
How many claimants were contacted?
What does the term ``non-exporters'' mean?

Is the Department saying that 14% do not exist or had no intention of exporting, or are they saying that 14% tried to export and failed? I would submit a 14% failure rate to be neither surprising nor a cause for alarm, however, I would strongly disagree that 14% were non-exporters and had no intention of exporting.
Our practice has in excess of 100 clients claiming EMDG Grants and everyone of these is genuinely trying to export.
(ii) Where did the ``indications'' come from that showed half of the claimants dropping out after three years?
Was it a result of the Department of Trade survey or was it from numbers supplied by the Export Development Grants Board?
If the figures come from the EDGB, then I think the so-called ``drop-outs'' would include re-arrangements such as;
(a) a Sole Trader becoming a Partnership or a Company, or any other combination of the above changes;
(b) a business undertaking being purchased by another entity;
(c) or possibly merely a change in name of the claimant.
Can the Minister provide factual information to show precisely what percentage of the half said to have dropped out are attributable to the above reasons.
(iii) Who are the other sources providing evidence of fraudulent abuse?
A few case histories on the effect of the proposed changes are;

1. A manufacturer of ladies swimwear has sold their products in South East Asia and New Zealand for some years. Their grant entitlement is always in excess of 7 1/2% of their export earnings because of high promotional expenses.

Immediately prior to the Minister's Press Release, the directors of the Company made a decision to invest $100,000 in a campaign to promote their goods in California. They made this decision on the basis that if their campaign failed, they would receive back 70% from the Government. With the 7 1/2% limitation, they are now faced with the prospect of not being entitled to any rebate on the $100,000, they have therefore cancelled the promotion in the U.S.A.

2. A small premium wine maker receives small EMD Grants and sells small amounts of premium wine to Europe, South East Asia and New Zealand. They can meet a reasonable export earnings test, but the disallowance of the first $5,000 will exclude them completely. Why should a small business such as this be penalized?

3. A major ship-building company promote heavily overseas and receive significant EMD Grants. The resultant export earnings are received intermittently and in some years their export earnings are minimal. There should be a provision allowing the carry forward of eligible expenditure which does not attract a grant. This company is the very type of industry the Government wants to encourage and now this company has indicated if the proposed changes are legislated, they will cease attempting to export.

4. One of Perth's leading architectural firms has launched a major campaign to establish itself in South East Asia. Very shortly their maximum grant entitlement will be limited to around 10% of export earnings. This limitation upon providers of services is completely unrealistic because of their very high promotional expenses e.g. they have prepared very expensive feasibility studies for in excess of 20 projects in South East Asia, the cost of a couple of these submissions being in excess of A$50,000 each and have only been successful in receiving one commission. Because of the intense international competition, they cannot expect a success rate of any better than one in ten, consequently, their export earnings will never be sufficient to cover their promotional expenses with a 7 1/2% of export earnings grant limitation. What should also be borne in mind is that if architects are successful, then work flows on to engineers, builders, building materials suppliers, interior fitting supplies etc. as well as creating a favourable climate in that country for the export of other Australian products and services. This firm have already indicated they will cease their export efforts.

5. A manufacturer of simple, inexpensive electric hot water systems has penetrated overseas markets to the extent where 70% of his production is exported. Because his product requires continual promotion to gain sales, his E.M.D. Grant is always well in excess of 7 1/2% of his export earnings. He will now be caught in a vicious circle e.g.
(a) Because of the 7 1/2% limitation, he will need to reduce his overseas advertising as his profit margin is insufficient to bear the whole cost.
(b) As a result of reduced advertising, his export sales will fall,
(c) With reduced export earnings, his EMD Grant entitlement will fall because of the 7 1/2% limitation,
(d) The cycle will continue to be repeated until this successful exporting manufacturer is forced to cease exporting altogether.

6. Another of our clients manufactures conveying equipment and exports throughout Europe from a subsidiary company in the U.K. All components are manufactured in W.A. and then assembled in the U.K. Because of the 7 1/2% limitation, they are faced with exactly the same predicament as the electrical manufacturer above.

7. A firm in Perth manufactures commercial and industrial lighting and competes in Australia with multinationals such as Philips. In the past two years they have received small EMD Grants for visits they made to Malaysia and Singapore. As a result of those visits, they have sold in excess of $250,000 worth of Australian made light fittings. However, under the proposed changes, they will receive virtually no grant because of the $5,000 threshhold and they are considered by the Minister to be not worthy of support.

8. Similarly, a craftsman manufactures grandfather clocks of exceptional quality (and price of course). Because of limited demand for these products, his export earnings will never be high-however, his EMD Grants are also small because of the limited promotion he undertakes. Why should this man be excluded under the $5,000 rule? His products go to influential people and will obviously create in the purchaser a favourable impression of the capacities and skills of Australian craftsmen.

9. In your own industry of computers, we have a client who launched a major campaign into South East Asia for their software and services. To effectively promote in the region, they have had to establish a promotional office in Kuala Lumpur staffed by highly skilled and expensive Australians. Within the next year their grant entitlement will be down to 12 1/2% of export earnings. Whilst they are achieving sales and making progress, their export earnings will never be high enough to enable them to recoup 70% of their promotional expenses. Because of the proposed changes, they are now in the process of scaling down the Malaysian office and will probably cease attempting to export completely. These are the very people the Government should be continuing to encourage.

10. The change-over date of 20.5.85 will have disastrous effects upon many people. We have two firms who have been promoting the sale of plant in China for a couple of years. After much negotiating and visits, they managed to secure a substantial contract, the catch is that the plant and equipment they supplied (worth millions of dollars) was shipped out in June, 1985, thus not being eligible earnings for the 1984-85 year. Because that is their only earnings for that year, they will not have a grant entitlement for 1984-85.

Similarly, a company has a manufacturing under license agreement in Malaysia. Under this agreement, royalties for the year are paid in June each year. Because their royalties for 1984-85 were not received until June, 1985, they will thus not receive a grant for 1984-85 because they will not have any export earnings.
David, I could provide many more examples of the adverse effect these proposed changes will have upon exporters but believe the above is sufficient to give you an idea of the impact of the changes.
Kind regards,
GRANT-AID PTY LTD
Denver Davies

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the same vein, I would like to say a few words about one particular exporter, a company which is a real success story for Australia. This is the story of Kimberley Seeds Pty Ltd. Part of the Managing Director's letter to me states:

SPEECH.PARA: Our specific problem is that we are in the process of negotiating a sale to Iran of A$100m of machinery but the catch for us is, if the changes to the EMDG are enacted as proposed;
(1) If we are successful in gaining the Iranian contract our exports for the next two years will be in excess of A$20m and will then be excluded.

(2) If we do not gain the Iranian contract we will not be able to obtain a reimbursement of our expenses because of the 7 1/2 per cent of export earnings grant limitation. If we do not gain the contract our export earnings for 1985-86 would be made up of: Seeds-$300,000; Machinery, $200,000-
making a total of $500,000. The letter continues:
This $500,000 would give us a grant entitlement of $37,500-at 7 1/2 per cent-
which is reading it from the Government's table-

This equates to a total expenditure of $55,000. However, to pursue the potential sales in Saudi Arabia and Iran we have to appoint representatives in both these countries. We anticipate expenses in the vicinity of $200,000 per annum for our offices in these countries.

In addition we will have our normal export promotional expenses such as air fares, brochures etc. In all our total expenditure for 1985-86 could approach $300,000 giving us a theoretical grant entitlement of the maximum of $200,000. As mentioned above if we are successful we will get nothing, if we are unsuccessful we get approximately $35,000.

Surely the EMDG scheme-a scheme that is meant to encourage incentives-should be better than this. I believe this is only one example of the type of transitional problems which we get. We believe that our amendment, which would carry out an averaging over three years of the upper limit for eligibility for the export scheme, will actually overcome this problem. We have proposed it to the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a real problem?
—It is a real problem for Kimberley Seeds.
—If you have made $20m in export sales are you going to be concerned about that amount of money?

—I think you would be. The budgets for these things can be very tight when one is trying to be competitive in one of these countries, especially when one is trying to move into the sort of markets that Kimberley Seeds is working in. I think the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will realise just how tight the world economy is in these areas. I commend companies such as Kimberley Seeds Pty Ltd and I deplore the fact that we are not giving them the type of incentive that they should get. I ask the Minister and the Opposition to consider supporting our amendments, which, I repeat, would cost the country nothing but would allow companies such as Kimberley Seeds to get a reasonable incentive for their exports. They must make decisions now.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1985. I welcome the opportunity to speak on the subject of trade because it is an area to which I believe we as a nation are not paying sufficient attention. This legislation will amend the original export market development grants scheme which, over a number of years, has provided quite useful incentives which were necessary for our manufacturers and exporters to penetrate overseas markets.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's objections to aspects of this legislation are well known. They were fully canvassed in the other House when the legislation was debated there. I accept and I understand that if we are to improve our rather sorry economic state, we must start first with cutbacks at government level and so the changes to this Bill were suggested at the time of the May mini-Budget. However, I do agree with the concerns of other Opposition speakers with the timing of the introduction of this Bill. I believe that it will create budgetary and accounting difficulties for exporters who will be caught in the changeover from the old rules to the new rules.

Another area in this legislation that concerns me relates to the new limits for grants. At one end of the scale a minimum of $5,000 must be expended before a grant will be paid. At the other end of the scale claimants with export earnings over $20m will also be excluded. The Tourist industry will be excluded completely from the scheme. On the question of the $5,000 minimum, I am not entirely sure why this figure was arrived at. There are, quite possibly, very valid administrative reasons.

One industry that will be adversely affected by this ruling is the wine industry. I consider that the wine industry should be a worthy recipient of assistance such as that which is available under this scheme. I believe that the Australian Trade Commissioner Service has provided quite valuable assistance in the past in the promotion and sale of Australian wines in a number of new markets. Markets such as Japan and South East Asia are two that come to mind. Industries such as the wine industry and other smaller industries need all the help that they can get. With the range of government measures that have adversely affected the grape growers and wine makers, I would have thought it time that they had some good news from the Government. But, the wine industry is another example of rural enterprise and small business and is therefore an industry to be forgotten by this Government.

What the Government fails to realise is that the Australian primary producers are responsible for over 40 per cent of Australia's overseas earnings. Despite enormous cost pressures that the rural sector has faced in recent years, it is important to remember that the increase of 24 per cent in exports in 1984-85 was due largely to our primary products, especially wheat and other cereals. I cannot emphasise too strongly just how important our overseas trade is to Australia. We are in an economic mess in this country at the moment, despite whatever rosy picture the Government tries to paint. Our overseas borrowings are enormous. It has been suggested that they are as high as $100 billion. The only way we can get ourselves out of this problem is to trade our way out. Over the past 30 years we have slipped in world trading figures, from being the eighth largest trader to being only the twenty-third. Countries such as Singapore, Taiwan and even Hong Kong are now ahead of us. Over the same period that we dropped as a world trading nation, our share of world export markets dropped from 2.6 per cent to 1.2 per cent. At the start of the century, Australia led the way in its standard of living. Eighty years on our standard of living is rapidly falling to Third World status. The international purchasing power of our exports has shown weak growth over the past 30 years. By comparison with other major trading nations, our purchasing power has declined.

Why has our trade performance been so poor? First and foremost, it is caused by our lack of competitiveness on world markets. Rising costs, particularly for our farmers, are making our products more and more expensive and therefore harder to sell on international markets. This problem has been exacerbated by inflation, because Australian farmers are price takers; they are not price makers or price setters. The need for incentives and a low rate of inflation is stronger in the rural sector than it is in other sectors of the economy. Farmers are unable to pass on increases in farm costs. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be raised and discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I would like to use the opportunity to make some remarks about a person called Hubert Giesberts, often known as Hughie Giesberts. I want to make these remarks because Mr Giesberts, a pensioner from the suburb of Pinkenba in Brisbane, has circulated to many honourable senators copies of correspondence he has had with a South African newspaper called the Citizen. The Citizen is published in Johannesburg. When Mr Giesberts circulated his correspondence that he had had with the South African newspaper, he also provided some other information which set out his philosophy about Australia's position and South Africa. Mr Giesberts has had a letter of his published in the Citizen, and this letter is quite pro-South Africa and the apartheid policy that South Africa currently condones. As well as that, it is quite anti-Australian. The letter in the Citizen is headed this way: `Hayden Speaks with a Forked Tongue'. Then it goes on further and develops an argument that Australia is quite wrong in its attitude towards South Africa; Mr Giesberts believes that South Africa is one of the best countries in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of Mr Giesberts's comments in his letter would be quite libellous, I would think, if they were published in an Australian newspaper. Whether the libel laws of South Africa apply if libellous comments are made about an Australian in South African newspapers, I just do not know. But because of Mr Giesberts's correspondence with South African newspapers and his having letters published in a South African newspaper, and because of the comments that he had made in correspondence that he has passed to many senators, it is worth while saying something about this person and putting in context just what he has been saying and what sort of support he has in Australia. From the letters he has sent to South African newspapers, I would say he has very little support in Australia, and I shall outline shortly how little support he has had when he has had the wish to seek election in Australia.

Mr Giesberts's letter and his comments attributed the South African crisis to a communist push of some sort in South Africa. He has accused Bishop Tutu and other clergy in South Africa of being communist agents for the KGB. He claims that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, condones communism. He admits to giving 100 per cent support to the South African Government in its endeavours to keep law and order. Typical of his comments is the statement that the South African people have `to endure communist organised boycotts, anarchy and terrorism'. Reading through Mr Giesberts's comments, one is obviously reminded of the phrase that we used to have in Australia: `Reds under the beds'. One would expect that Mr Giesberts would see those; but more than that, he seems to carry reds in his pocket. His writings are quite schizophrenic and sometimes unintelligible, but one does get the general drift of them-that he is quite pro-South African and quite anti-Australian.

I would like to stress this afternoon, to Australians but more specifically to a gullible South African Press, that Mr Giesberts's meandering letters and comments are not those of a typical Australian. To indicate why they are not typical, I would like to mention something about this person's background. Mr Giesberts was originally a Dutch citizen. Perhaps the fact that he is a Dutch citizen has something to do with his support of the South African apartheid system. Mr Giesberts is now 74 years old. He migrated to Australia in 1953 from Holland. It was not until 1966 that he sought and gained naturalisation. That was after living for 13 years in Australia. I do not know why Mr Giesberts waited for 13 years, but he waited 13 years before he was naturalised. Mr Giesberts worked as a Brisbane City Council labourer for over 20 years. He has a reputation of being an eccentric stirrer. In fact, he likes to be called a stirrer. He says that is what he aims to be. He does not say that he is an eccentric stirrer, but it is my opinion that he is. Mr Giesberts has been aligned with various organisations, the most recent one being the `Get us out of the United Nations Campaign'. He has also been involved with the Pensioners Party of Australia, Social Credit, New Economics, and the Australian Pensioners Pressure Group.

I indicated that he did become naturalised in 1966. Almost immediately thereafter, he started to seek election to the Brisbane City Council, the State Parliament of Queensland, or the Federal Parliament. I am not sure whether that is why he took out his citizenship after 13 years, but it is significant that almost immediately after 1966, when he became a naturalised Australian, he started to seek election. Since then, he has become a perennial election candidate. He had of course, as I said, sought election at the Brisbane City Council, State and Federal levels, but it is important to indicate that he has been unsuccessful on each occasion.

The first time Mr Giesberts sought election was in 1967, for the Brisbane City Council. He stood as an independent candidate for the ward of Nudgee. On that occasion he received 518 votes out of total of 13,787 cast; so he received a very small percentage of the votes. Not worried about that, two years later, in 1969, he stood for the Queensland state election as a Social Credit candidate. The seat had the same name as the ward that he had previously stood for-the seat was Nudgee-and he received 335 votes or 2.4 per cent. I am indicating the size of the vote that Mr Giesberts has received to indicate that he does not have wide support; in fact, he has only very narrow support when he seeks election to bodies in Queensland. In 1970, a year after he had received 2.4 per cent of the vote in his bid to go into the Queensland Parliament, he again stood for the Brisbane City Council. On that occasion he called himself a Liberal Civic candidate. This time the ward was Sandgate. He improved his vote over the 1969 vote but he did not have the same vote as he had in 1967. He received 348 votes out of a total of 11,840 that were cast-again a very small percentage.

In 1974 I had some close dealings with Mr Giesberts, as it was in 1974 that I stood for the Senate, for the second time. In the 1974 Senate election, Mr Giesberts was one of the ungrouped candidates and he received 832 votes. Putting that in perspective, there were over a million votes cast on that occasion and out of that million Mr Giesberts received 832 votes. I have not worked out that percentage, but it is fairly easy, and it gives an indication of the very narrow support that Mr Giesberts received- especially by then having become a noted candidate, having stood in 1967, 1969 and 1970.

Most honourable senators will remember that in 1975 in this place we had a casual vacancy because of the death of Bert Milliner. The Queensland Government was charged with the responsibility of appointing a person to take Bert Milliner's place. Some might remember that a person called Field came into this place in place of the nominee of the Australian Labor Party, who was a high calibre and well respected candidate. Before that happened, however, Mr Giesberts contacted Mr Bjelke-Petersen, as he then was-now Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-and asked Mr Bjelke-Petersen to appoint him to the casual vacancy. Apparently Mr Bjelke-Petersen decided that he was not quite foolish enough and appointed Mr Field instead.

Unfazed by being rejected on that occasion, Mr Giesberts stood again for the Senate in the 1975 election-I suppose I did too, but on that occasion I was successful. Out of well over a million votes cast, he received 634. Mr Giesberts has shown a lot of persistence. He would have stood for the Senate in 1977 but he could not raise the $200 deposit, and he made quite an impassioned plea that this could not be right because there was nothing in the Constitution that mentioned that one had to have a deposit. Perhaps Mr Giesberts should read the Constitution and see where laws can be made in this respect. He gave notice that he would stand for the House of Representatives in the seat of Lilley in 1984. He said in part of his policy speech that he would not take a salary because that was not needed; but it never eventuated. He did not stand in 1984, for some reason of which I am not sure. In 1985, this year, he wanted to stand again for a Brisbane City Council election, and he made a plea for people to help him raise his deposit of, I think, $250. He was going to run for the position of Lord Mayor, but as he did not have the money to nominate, he did not run.

I am not sure whether Mr Giesberts is going to run again for public office. It is his right to do so of course. I would not be surprised to see him there again. The point that I would like to make is that every time Mr Giesberts has run, he has had a dismal failure in the polls. I would like those people in South Africa who read his letters in the newspapers, to understand that he is not representative of the Australian people, and certainly not representative of the Brisbane people and the suburbs from which he comes.

There are a number of eccentric incidents that I would have liked to cover but I see that my time has nearly run out. However, they include Mr Giesberts charging admission to listen to his policy speech, and having five people come along to hear him, and refusing to lodge tax returns because he could not see that this was required within the Constitution. What I would like to say, in conclusion, is that those who read his letters and his comments should not take him seriously. The message to the South African Government's newspapers is that his letters do not reflect an Australian opinion; they are simply the opinion of an elderly, strange and, perhaps, eccentric man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, there is an unfortunate Australian tradition of seldom recognising artists or people of distinction as they progress along the journey of their chosen careers. Fortunately, there are exceptions or pockets of light where encouragement is given to Australians of national and international repute. Sale in Victoria is one such town which has become a mecca for artists, writers and other creative people. However, while much revenue is generated from this area, little is returned to the arts. To compound these difficulties, the Sale Gallery has not received funding from the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council since 1976, despite annual submissions. However, a number of craft items on display at the gallery from time to time have been purchased with the assistance of the Crafts Board of the Australia Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, such financial or material matters have not dismayed people such as: Charles McCubbin, a painter and an expert in butterflies and a consultant to the Zoological Board of Victoria; writer Marion le Cheminant; and artists Marie Ingrouille and Annemieke Mein-to name but a few.

Earlier this week I was one of a number who were privileged to be invited by Peter Synan, the Mayor of Sale, to attend a public reception given in honour of, perhaps, Australia's most talented artist, Annemieke Mein, in recognition of her creative genius in designing of the six bronze sculptures erected in the Sale Mall. Peter Synan is not the typical town mayor coming from the traditional backgrounds of the legal fraternity or the business community. Peter is a school teacher, with special interests in history. He envisaged the need for the council to acknowledge in an appropriate way the efforts of some of the district's early pioneers. It was Peter Synan's brainchild to erect a `Wall of Fame' on to which Annemieke's bronze sculptures were erected.

I believe that the Mayor and the City of Sale are to be congratulated on their vision in supporting the installation of these six fine sculp- tures depicting such important local identities as Nehemiah Guthridge; Angus McMillan; the explorer, naturalist, scientist and anthropologist, Alfred William Howitt; Shire President, Premier of Victoria, and first member of the House of Representatives in Federal Parliament, Allan McLean; a royal command singer, Ada Crossley; and the well known author of the Billabong series and author of other famous works, Mary Grant Bruce.

This artist, Annemieke Mein, who was responsible for the design of these sculptures, has skills in a variety of mediums, including sketching, painting, applique and machine embroidery. She has received both national and international acclaim. In fact, those who know her will remember her highly successful exhibitions, which have been held in Hong Kong, London and Edinburgh, and the frequency of her work appearing in Australian journals and other periodicals. Her work is held in such high regard that she was asked to prepare an exhibit for the permanent display in the new permanent Parliament House in Canberra, which is due to be opened in 1988, our bicentennial year.

Unfortunately for Australia, government red tape imposed just so many restrictions on both her time and her creativity that she felt that she had to decline this invitation. Like so many other outstanding artists, Annemieke has found that the spark of creative genius stems from an empathy with nature. There is an obvious love of life-of all creation-in her work. Her brilliance is tied up with her attention to detail and her knowledge of what makes living things tick. So often the great achievers of this world are to be found not in the metropolitan areas but in the country, closer to the world of nature. I am sure that those bronze sculptures displayed in the Sale Mall will be much admired and cared for by the people of Sale and be a source of pleasure and inspiration to all those who take the time to stop and examine them.

Mr Deputy President, I seek the leave of the Senate to table some notes regarding the inspiration, ideas, concepts, philosophy constraints and execution of the six historical bas-relief bronzes, so that the wider community can appreciate the genius and the meticulous attention to detail of a great Australian artist, Annemieke Mein.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that many may be inspired by her works of art.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, will be absent from the chamber both today and tomorrow. She is attending the Australian Education Council meeting in Western Australia. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Ryan in relation to her portfolio, or to those she represents in this chamber, should be directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, relates to the proposed tax on fringe benefits and to the Government's decision to limit exemptions from that tax to religious bodies only. Is the Minister aware that the non-cash fringe benefits tax will be payable by welfare agencies in relation to some benefits that cannot be considered either as tax minimisation or as tax avoidance. I give the Minister as examples accommodation provided to house parents, who may be getting salaries of $12,500, who are providing live-in care for people with disabilities; accommodation provided to staff members on 24-hour call; and small mini-buses used to pick up the disabled which are taken home by drivers who make the pick-ups on their way to work. As payment of this new tax by welfare agencies can be made only at the cost of cutting back on services to the needy, will the Government amend its proposal and overcome this anomaly-yet another anomaly-in the tax package which will hurt the most needy groups in the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am touched at the new-found concern in the Liberal Party of Australia for the welfare of the needy. Senator Peter Baume referred to what he called an anomaly. I think one of the problems that the Opposition has, and one of the reasons why it had such a disastrous record in economic management, is that it seems to be incapable of taking an overview. The Opposition sees the responsibility of government as responding to each individual pressure group as it appears and accommodating the wishes of each individual pressure group. Consequently, we have the Opposition fiercely defending the free lunches, the free car and any vested interest that cares to put its case to it. It is because the Opposition behaved in that way in government that ultimately, at the end of its disastrous seven-year term, we had double digit inflation, double digit unemployment, a contracting economy and 180,000 jobs destroyed in just one year. By contrast, of course, almost half a million new jobs have been created since this Government came to office. That is by way of general observation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Peter Baume asserted that, in a number of quite specific cases, the employing organisations-he gave the hypothetical example of welfare agencies-would be liable to taxation. Frankly, I do not know whether or not they would be taxed in those situations but I will seek a definitive response from the Australian Taxation Office via the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force figures for September? Do the figures underline the continuing success of the Government's economic and employment policies?
—That must be a surprise question to you!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a surprise on this occasion. Of course I have seen the ABS figures on employment and I think they are encouraging. The September labour force figures, released at 11.30 this morning, are clear evidence of the success of the Government's economic policies and they are good news for the unemployed. Unemployment is now at its lowest level for three years. Employment grew by a massive 56,500 last month and the unemployment rate was reduced to 8.1 per cent-the lowest rate since September 1982. I make the additional point-I suppose this concerns the Opposition about as much as free lunches-that the participation rate stood at 61.1 per cent compared with 60.6 per cent in September 1984. In the last 12 months there have been fluctuating figures in the participation rate but there has been a general increase in that rate. I just make this point in passing: A one per cent increase in the participation rate is equivalent to 10,000 jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: Since this Government came to office over 487,000 jobs have been created; that is, since April 1983. The Government is now close to achieving its target of 500,000 new jobs in three years. In fact, job growth of 103,500 since June means that we are now well ahead of the Budget prediction of 180,000 jobs for employment growth during 1985-86.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many in the public sector?

—I am coming to that. Almost three-quarters of this job growth has been in full time employment. An important feature of the figures which will appeal to Senator Crichton-Browne is the growth in the private sector. Eighty-six per cent of employment growth over the year to August 1985 has been in industries operating in the private sector. Those are very encouraging figures to the Government; but clearly, there is a long way to go and the Government is not satisfied and cannot be satisfied with the position as it currently stands. The point I want to make is that very substantial progress is being made.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked by Senator Chipp by way of interjection whether I would be aware of the unemployment figures. Of course I watch for them every month and I think they are a very important indicator of the success of the recovery. In spite of the ideological carping of the Opposition, of which we have heard a lot in the last couple of days, they underpin the continued success of the accord and the results which are being produced. What this Government has to offer is jobs and continued growth. The figures demonstrate a lot of the nonsense which has been talked in opposition-calls for the abandonment of the accord and the Government's wages policy and a return to some half-baked smorgasbord of deregulated industrial relations systems and the sort of mess we had in 1982, presided over substantially by the present Leader of the Opposition. Once again one can say that there is cautious encouragement and optimism in these figures-probably a little more encouragement and optimism than we have received in the steady progression in increases in employment in this country and in reductions of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the paper from which he has quoted.
—The Minister has been requested to table the paper from which he has quoted.
—I table the paper.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, refers to the Government's wholesale sales tax decisions which have increased the price of household items such as ovens, refrigerators, washing machines and vacuum cleaners. How does the Minister justify the decision to impose or increase these taxes on essential household equipment when in the Budget it decided to remove sales tax from imported thoroughbred race horses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is at the margin, I think, always some room to quibble about items that should or should not be on the wholesale sales tax list or the rate at which they should be taxed. As to the specific items to which Senator Teague referred, a judgment was made by the Government that they were conceptually linked to a number of other items which were already in the Schedule and, therefore, ought to go in and at the same rate. If Senator Teague is really worried about essential household equipment being subject to tax or, indeed, about any extension of the wholesale sales tax at all, I wonder how he reconciles that with Senator Messner's tax policy? I am not sure whether or not this is the tax policy of the Opposition. It is very difficult to keep track of what is the current tax policy of the Opposition because it changes every day and it changes even within one day depending on whether one listens to Senator Messner or Mr Howard, or to somebody else.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Messner's latest will and testament on this subject, as far as I know, is that there would be an extension of the wholesale sales tax and the introduction of a services tax. If Senator Teague is concerned about items being subject to tax, I wonder how he reconciles that concern with the policy of his Party's taxation spokesman. I do not really think that I can add anything to that, other than to say that judgments at the margin are always involved in determining the schedule of taxable items and the rate at which they will be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Did the manager of Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Queensland, Mr Bob Hailstone, formerly have a similar position in Canberra? If so, what was his position and was he fully or partly responsible for the decision to discontinue the racing service on Canberra radio? Was the Canberra ABC racing service taken off air while Mr Hailstone was in Canberra and what was the reason given after that decision? Was the service subsequently reinstated? Would it be appropriate to draw certain conclusions, or is it mere coincidence that the ABC racing service was discontinued in two cities at the time Mr Hailstone held a senior position with ABC radio in those two cities?
—I had a note on this matter but I seem to have misplaced it. I will try to give some information on it to Senator Colston at the end of Question Time.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Is it true that a majority of Australians have been misled into believing that the United States would automatically defend Australia under the terms of the ANZUS Treaty in time of attack by a foreign power? Have successive governments, both Labor and Liberal, mortgaged our future by allowing 24 foreign bases on our soil which according to the Australian and Soviet governments make us nuclear targets? Was New Zealand, a member of ANZUS, attacked recently by a foreign power? Was that foreign power France? Did the United States refuse even to officially protest to France or to support New Zealand's claim for compensation? Is this not concrete and practical evidence that ANZUS is absolutely devoid of any meaning and useless to any of the signatories other than the United States of America?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp's views on ANZUS are well known and have been articulated in this place on a number of occasions. They are not views which are shared by the Government, the Opposition or indeed by the overwhelming majority of Australians, who see ANZUS as being an extremely important security treaty demonstrative of an extremely important alliance relationship. It is not only important for its own terms but also important as demonstrating a solid component of the world-wide alliance of the Western nations which is a crucial part of the process of maintaining world peace in an unstable world environment.

ANSWER.PARA: The rationale for ANZUS has a number of dimensions which are not entirely dependent on the strict letter of its potential application in any conflict. I do not think that even the most extravagant interpretation of the operation of ANZUS would suggest that the Rainbow Warrior affair in New Zealand represents the kind of hostility that gives rise to any obligation on the part of the United States or Australia, as co-partners in the ANZUS Treaty, to leap into their warships and come steaming to the aid of the beleaguered little battler of the South Pacific. That is a highly extravagant and fanciful interpretation which Senator Chipp articulated a moment ago in describing ANZUS in the coloured terms he did. Many more things could be said on this subject, but perhaps it is one that would be better debated at length rather than at Question Time.
