TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I asked one question in three parts; I plead with the Minister to answer just one of them. Was France the foreign power that attacked New Zealand recently and did the United States even officially protest to France or support New Zealand's claim for compensation for that attack?

—I do not see that that bears any relationship to the thrust of the question, which was about ANZUS. As to the United States reaction to the Rainbow Warrior affair, I recall that there was a reaction from the United States Government. I will have to remind myself of the terms of that reaction.
—You have had the question since 10 o'clock this morning.
—I have not had the question. I do not have it in front of me now.
—You had it in your office.
—I did not have it in my office and I do not have it now. I am sorry. If Senator Chipp wants some further information on any of these matters, I will dig it out and bring it to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I refer to two aircraft accidents resulting in substantial loss of life in recent months and involving aircraft with engines similar to those widely used in Australia; namely, a Boeing 737 in Manchester, United Kingdom, and a DC9 aircraft in Milwaukee, United States of America. Will the Minister outline current information held by Australian authorities on the circumstances of the United States accident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two major aircraft accidents resulting in substantial loss of life in recent months have involved aircraft with engines similar to those widely used in Australia. I refer to the Boeing 737 in Manchester, United Kingdom and the DC9 aircraft in Milwaukee, United States of America. In the Australian context, similar aircraft are used. Naturally, the Department of Aviation has been monitoring this considerably. We all have a somewhat vested interest in this area because members of parliament, as well as public servants and the community generally, use aircraft frequently. The Minister for Aviation has directed the Department to monitor the situation. We have sent an officer to the UK to be present at the inquiry being held.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is confident that all steps have been taken to monitor any weaknesses that exist in the Pratt and Whitney engines. Even though the engines were supplied by the same company, they are of a different variety. In no way can it be said that the failure of the engines arose because they were made by the same company because they were not the same engines and the reasons for the crashes were different on each occasion. However, the Government is aware of its responsibilities in this matter and is keeping the matter constantly under review.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister accept that quarantining farm losses discriminates against agriculture when compared with the negative gearing on rental properties, because the latter will apply only to investments from 18 July 1985? How can the Minister justify applying the quarantining provisions in respect of rural farm losses to existing investments, which has a retrospective effect in respect of farm property investments? Is this just another sign of the Government's prejudice against the people of rural Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that the quarantining of farm losses will apply to properties already owned. The reason for that and the minor distinction between the treatment of that and negative gearing of rental properties is that investment on agricultural land can continue for a very long period, whereas the negatively geared rental properties either are built or will be built and completed in the very near future. That is the basic reason for the different treatment of the two. Senator Brownhill said that it will penalise agriculture, or words to that effect. That is sheer nonsense. The existence of the farm losses tax shelter has pushed up farming land prices to extraordinarily and unsustainably high levels paid by city based investors-Pitt Street, Collins Street, St George's Terrace farmers and so on which genuine farmers could not afford to pay. I understand that Senator Brownhill has an agricultural background. Therefore he ought to know that anybody who either is and wants to remain or wants to become a farmer knows that lower land prices are advantageous and that higher land prices impose a penalty.

ANSWER.PARA: Among the more absurd arguments put up by the National Farmers Federation on the taxation package is that because of taxation changes it will be extremely difficult to attract new capital investment into long term low yielding investments such as agriculture; begging the question as to why any sensible government would want deliberately to attract new capital investment into low yielding industries. It was disappointing that the National Farmers Federation backed such an absurd position. It is even more disappointing that the present Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia supported that, and for exactly the same reasons. Not even Malcolm Fraser would have done that.

If the return on capital investment in any industry is extraordinarily low, that is a signal from the market place that the investable funds ought to be directed elsewhere. I find it particularly ironic that the Liberal Party, under its new allegedly ideological leadership-an ideology which is supposed to support market forces-cannot either recognise that simple proposition or translate it into policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Did I hear the Minister correctly? Did he say that the tax reform package would lower farm land values?

—No, I did not say that. I said that the existence of the agricultural tax shelter and the expectation of untaxed capital gains had pushed land prices up to levels which were unsustainably high. They had started to come down long before there were falls in Western Australia, probably of the order of 30 per cent over the last two years. Land prices were on the way down in any case from unsustainably high levels, to which they were forced by Pitt Street farmers, Collins Street farmers and their ilk taking advantage of the tax shelter provisions, which the honourable senator apparently still defends and pushing land prices up to levels which could not be afforded or paid by genuine, ordinary farmers, whom I understand the honourable senator purports to represent.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. Has the Government yet examined the recommendations of the task force which reported on repetition strain injury in the Australian Public Service? If not, can the Minister indicate when the Government's response might be expected? Is it correct, as reported on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning, that repetition strain injury victims returning to light duties are being paid reduced wages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of the question, I am advised that the Commissioner for Employees Compensation has issued an advice to departments and authorities about payments to be made to staff including those suffering from RSI who return to work for less than full daily hours for a period. The Public Service Board, for which I have some responsibility on behalf of the Prime Minister, was not involved in that action. It is understood that it resulted from representations made to the Commissioner that cases were occurring where such staff were not receiving their full entitlements under the Act.

ANSWER.PARA: In reply to the rest of the question, I have looked at the task force report and had some discussions with officers of both the Public Service Board and the Department of Finance. I am sorry that I cannot put a firm date on this, but I expect to lodge a submission to Cabinet before the end of this year.

One thing which I think can be considered independently of the final government judgment on this is that under the present service-wide arrangements for staffing controls people who are away from work because of RSI or any other cause are still counted as active operating staff unless they are away from work for more than three months. So there is an incentive, in a desire to maintain staffing levels, to put people off for three months and then get replacements. That is certainly not in the interests of efficient management of total Public Service staff numbers and probably not in the interests of the individuals concerned.

There is one other matter on which I wish to comment, which I think points to complexities of this question in dealing with that report and the information it revealed. In the same work designations and in the same departments, but in different cities, there are reported incidents of RSI which vary from 44 per cent to zero. Obviously such an enormous disparity in the reported incidence of the complaint is very difficult to explain and I think draws attention to the overall problem of dealing with this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. I refer to an article in yesterday's Age newspaper where it was reported that the Special Minister of State had agreed to review the rationing of free national flags. I ask: Firstly, in view of the widespread community demand for the retention and display of the Australian national flag, will the Minister now ensure that community organisations will once again have access to free national flags? Secondly, was the decision to limit the availability of flags made on purely budgetary grounds? If not, what other factors were taken into account? Thirdly, does the Government accept that the national pride and spirit that flourish when our flag is flown is worth to this nation far in excess of the relatively small Budget allocation that would be required to restore the arrangements to their former satisfactory state?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear Senator Vanstone on the wavelength of her generation and acutely conscious of the ebb and flow of the main issues of our time.
—It is a pity you don't get on the wavelength of your generation, or any generation.
—I heard a geriatric squeak over there, Mr President, but I will not-
—Order!
—Get your hands out of your pockets when you are talking to the headmaster. Get your hands out of your pockets, you naughty little boy.
—Order! I ask Senator Evans to answer Senator Vanstone.
—What an undergraduate twit.
—I would like that to be recorded as demonstrative of the quality of the interjections we are now getting from the Leader of the Opposition.
—I would too, under my name, you failed Attorney-General.
—Order, Senator Chaney!
—I am sorry, Mr President. To ensure that it is in the Hansard, I just interjected that he is a failed Attorney-General.
—Order! I call Senator Evans.

—If we may move on from this adolescent extravaganza to which we have just been treated by the Leader of the Opposition I advise Senator Vanstone that the new arrangements-according to the Special Minister of State-were commenced following heavy demands by some members in the first two months of the financial year. Over 1,200 flags were issued in July and August. In order that the remaining supply of flags was available to members and senators on an equitable basis, Mr Young wrote to members and senators informing them of their entitlements for the remainder of the year. The new system also allowed members and senators to make their own decisions on distribution of flags within the government guidelines.

ANSWER.PARA: However, following strong representations from a number of members to the effect that they preferred the previous system, Mr Young advises me that he has decided to revert to the old approach. He says that there has been no Budget cutback in the free issue program and that the same number of flags will be available this year as last year, requiring an increased financial allocation. If the demand continues at the present rate the Government may have to consider the matter in Additional Estimates. At that time we would, of course, take into account the Opposition's calls for restraint in government expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In the light of Press reports today linking the Queensland Minister for Main Roads with the rerouting of Queensland roads for the benefit of his family and friends, and in view of the fact that last year the Federal Government gave $1.80 for every $1 the Queensland Government gave to road funding in that State, will the Minister assure Queensland taxpayers that Federal Government road funds for Queensland cannot be similarly misused by Queensland Ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot comment on the validity of the Press reports. However, I am not surprised about the allegations that have been made about the way in which the Queensland Government distributes its road funds. On the evidence I have before me it appears that the Queensland Government distributes road funds, particularly those provided by the Commonwealth, in a very unbalanced and discriminatory way. That follows a pattern that some State governments have pursued over the years. The Queensland Government in particular has made it a matter of major principle. The evidence seems to indicate and the breakdown of funds shows that money that is allocated by the Commonwealth is directed to the south east portion of Queensland. If that is done on the basis of some form of patronage it ignores the basic criterion of the Commonwealth legislation which is that allocations should be based on the needs of the particular area. Directing the funds to the south east corner of Queensland is to the detriment of central and northern Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Everyone appreciates the need for road works to be provided to meet the needs of communities. Nevertheless, funds for that purpose should be directed in a way that could be described as equitable and proper. That is not what is happening in Queensland. It is interesting to note that for several years now most of the funding for Queensland roads has been provided by the Commonwealth Government. The Queensland Government is paying less and less of its funds for road purposes. For example, the present Federal Government provides about 65 per cent of the total amount of money spent by the Queensland Department of Main Roads. In this financial year the Commonwealth will spend $257.6m on Queensland roads, which represents an increase of 84.8 per cent on 1981-82, the last full year of the Fraser Government.

No other State has performed as badly as Queensland in matching the Federal road effort. With the recent reduction of the Federal Government's historic Australian land transport program, greater accountability in spending Federal money will be looked for by the Commonwealth to ensure that the Queensland Government makes its due contribution to the roadworks programs in that State.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his statement today about unemployment figures. I ask: Does he agree with the Prime Minister that at least 130,000 new jobs are necessary each year merely, in the Prime Minister's words, to provide for population growth without creating any new jobs at all for the existing unemployed? Does not this mean that at least 350,000 new jobs were necessary just to keep pace with the population growth during the two years and eight months of the Hawke Government? Does not this mean that no more than 50,000 new jobs at the very most, and probably much fewer than that, have been created in those almost three years? Has not the participation rate been almost continually lower during the Hawke Government's term of office than in the Fraser Government's term, thereby disguising the real level of high unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My recollection is that in the last year of the Fraser Government the participation rate went down considerably, as one might expect. Because there was such a crisis of confidence in this country people packed their bags and went home in terms of seeking employment. That is not surprising because close to 250,000 jobs were lost in that period. If I might use a term from an old story, Senator Sir John Carrick uses statistics like a drunk uses a lamp post-for support rather than illumination. The effect of the statistics he uses is to suggest that if one sets off jobs created against the requirement for jobs the net increase in actual employment has been only 50,000 since the Government came to office. That is not supported by the aggregate unemployment figures. If one looks at the percentage decline in unemployment one will find that it is not supported. I am not sure whether the figures to which Senator Sir John Carrick referred in particular are correct. I have not examined them.
—They were used in the Budget Speech.

—Presumably Senator Sir John Carrick now quotes from the policy speech made by the Prime Minister. It is certainly true that, in order to accommodate the increase in the labour force which takes place annually, one has to create a significant number of jobs. Senator Sir John Carrick says that it is 130,000. Even on the basis of his own calculations he puts to me that 350,000 new jobs would have had to have been created by this Government to accommodate the increase in the labour force. The fact is that 484,000 new jobs have been created by this Government. The difference is a little more than 50,000, even if only on the basis of a simple mathematical calculation.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know the purpose of Senator Sir John Carrick's question. Is it to make some law moot debating point? I have not come into this chamber today at the start of Question Time boasting about the reduction in unemployment which this Government has achieved after the disastrous record of Senator Sir John Carrick's Government. I have not come in here saying that we are satisfied with the present level of unemployment. I never have. Repeatedly in this chamber I have said that the figures provide grounds for, perhaps, cautious optimism at the best. We cannot be satisfied as a government. However, we can be satisfied that we are going along totally the opposite route to the route Senator Sir John Carrick's Government went along. Unemployment is going down under this Government, whereas it was going up under his Government. We can be satisfied about those sorts of things.
On the road which this Government has embarked on, which has seen high levels of growth rates such as were not attained in Senator Sir John Carrick's period of government--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you-

—And such as Senator Watson also did not attain in his period of government, these sorts of employment figures are being produced. That is encouraging to the Government. It ought to be encouraging to every Australian who is concerned about this issue. I put it no higher than that. I am not trying to make debating points out of it. Perhaps Senator Sir John Carrick is. I want to be quite clear about the overall picture-the direction which this Government is following and the importance which we attach to the progress which is being made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Leader of the Government in the Senate that in his statement earlier he stated that the participation rate in employment was some 61.2 per cent or 61.1 per cent. He claimed that it was higher and asserted that it was a sign of achievement and progress. I ask the Government Leader: Is it not a fact that during almost the whole term of the Hawke Government the participation rate in employment has been in the 60 point something per cent area, and below the participation rate achieved by the Fraser Government, therefore disguising the unemployment level? That was the question I asked. If the participation rate was such, then any suggestion of a fall in unemployment is related to wrong figures indeed. I ask the Leader to direct himself to that question.
—I did not refer to the participation rate in my answer in any way saying that I was-
—It was in your first statement.

—I do not know what the honourable senator is talking about when he says `my first statement'. I suppose that he means the answer to the first question that I gave today. That is what I am referring to. I referred to the participation rate as being 61.1 per cent. The point I was making about the participation rate is simply this: The figure of 56,000, which is the reduction in unemployment, is really much better than it looks if one takes account of the increased participation rate. That is all I am saying. The fact is that one per cent in the participation rate is equivalent to 10,000 jobs. I will put that in simple terms so that the honourable senator might understand. The fact is that the unemployment reduction figure would have been larger-it probably would have been 66,000 or something of that order-if the participation rate had not increased. I only referred to the participation rate as being indicative of a sign of confidence in the community-
—And is a fall a sign of lack of confidence?
—Yes, I think that would be true.
—Order! Can we stop this chit chat and get on with Question Time?

—Mr President, with the greatest respect I regret that my answer to a question should be referred to as `chit chat'. The fact is that any fall in the participation rate, if it continued over a long period, would be regarded as a sign of lack of confidence in the overall well-being of the economy. I think that is probably correct. If one looks at the participation rate over this period of government one sees that it has been reflected in fluctuations from time to time.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Some time ago the Commonwealth offered to sell Tasman Island back to Tasmania for a nominal sum. Is there any reason why the proposed transfer has not yet occurred?

—I understand that in January 1983 the Commonwealth Government offered to sell Tasman Island, which is off the south-east corner of Tasmania, to the Tasmanian Government for $25,000. That was considered a fair and reasonable price but it was rejected by the Tasmanian Government. In May of this year the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Mr Uren, offered it to the Tasmanian Government for $100 on the condition that the Commonwealth Government could maintain the existing lighthouse, that the island would be dedicated for conservation purposes and that the existing historical structures would be maintained. Correspondence was entered into between the two governments and as late as July the Tasmanian Government indicated to the Federal Minister that the matter was under urgent consideration. To date-that is, the first week of October-the Tasmanian Government has not taken up the offer and one wonders why this matter is still in abeyance and has still not been concluded when such a nominal sum is involved. One can only suggest that the Tasmanian Government is rather reluctant to accept the conditions which, I think correctly, the Government has imposed on the Tasmanian Government for the very nominal sum that has been suggested. I suggest to the Tasmanian Government that it hurry up and finalise the proposals or the Federal Government might be persuaded to sell the island to someone like Holmes a Court.

—Is the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that Rotary International is a non-political and non-religious organisation of more than 800,000 members who provide community services to more than 148 countries? Is the Minister aware that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has refused visas to some South Africans Rotarians to play golf in Australia? If Rotarian golfers can be refused entry, is it the intention of this socialist Government to refuse the entry of South Africans or others who wish to engage in other Rotarian programs, such as group study exchanges and youth exchanges? Is the Minister prepared to assure Rotarians that they should continue to act as non-political and non-religious clubs? As these Rotarians from South Africa were assured initially that visas would be provided, will he reverse this decision which is viewed by a considerable number of fair-minded Australians as reprehensible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the Government, not just the Minister for Foreign Affairs, made a decision last month not to allow certain South African nationals to come into Australia to take part in the Twenty-second International Golfing Fellowship of the Rotary World Championships to be held in Melbourne this month. It is also the case, as Senator Jessop says, that Rotary is an organisation of great and unblemished reputation and nothing in the Government's decision is to be taken as or was intended to reflect in any way on that admirable reputation.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision was taken in the following circumstances: In 1983 the Government undertook a major review of policy towards sporting contacts with South Africa, whether they occured in South Africa, Australia, or third countries and whether they involved individual sportsmen or sporting teams. In October 1983 the results of that review were publicly announced. Under the policy, which is firmly based on the 1977 Gleneagles Declaration on apartheid in sport and the 1982 Brisbane code of conduct, all individual amateur South African sports men and women would be considered as representative of South Africa unless there were definite proof to the contrary and would not be allowed entry to Australia to participate in international sporting competitions. No South African sporting team would be allowed entry to Australia, but individual professional sports persons would be assumed to be non-representative unless there were proof to the contrary and would be permitted entry into Australia, the point being taken in that policy development that by and large professional sportsmen, particularly individual sportsmen such as golfers, tend not be participating in competitions in any representative sense at all.

The Government's decision, as I stated in announcing it last night, was not based on the fact that the golfers are Rotarians. The decision was made in accordance with the Government's commitments under the Gleneagles Declaration and in accordance with that policy on sporting contacts announced in October 1983 and recently reaffirmed on 19 August this year. Our position is clear and it follows from our commitment to the Gleneagles Declaration whereby we undertook, as did our predecessor, to withold support from and take every practical step to discourage sporting contacts with South Africa. Let me make it plain that the decision is in accord with that Government policy and it is quite clear that, had entry been granted, South African nationals would have been taking part here in an international sporting competition-albeit one of not a very high level, but an international sporting contest, notwithstanding. That was perceived by us as a clear breach of Government policy.

I conclude by saying that the Government's policy on sporting contacts is long-standing and has, at least hitherto, enjoyed strong bipartisan support. The policy as applied by Australia and other countries has been successful in strengthening the situation whereby South Africa has been isolated in international sport, and that has been a significant source of pressure in producing the recent events which have given some confidence for the longer term future of reform in that country. The sporting contacts policy has also been a strong and effective reminder of the international community's general abhorrence of apartheid. If, on occasion, the implementation of that policy seems in some quarters to be harsh that is the price we all have to pay to register with South Africa and every South African the international community's determination to see apartheid abolished.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. The Minister did not allude to the part of my question which asked whether it is the intention of the Government to prevent students who wish to engage in Rotary programs such as group studies exchanges and youth exchange programs coming here.

—I apologise for the oversight. It was so manifestly absurd an extrapolation from the decision in this instance that I did overlook it in my reply. Of course, it is not the Government's intention to act in such a way in relation to Rotarians or anybody else. The policy is a policy about sporting contacts and it has been applied and will be applied in that context.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Aviation would be aware of the crash of a Pelair jet airliner at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport this morning killing the two pilots. In view of the curfew on jet aircraft at Mascot and the fact that it was a Pelair aircraft that has apparently been investigated in New Guinea recently in respect of possible drug trafficking, is there anything unusual in this crash?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be aware that a light aircraft crashed in Botany Bay in the early hours of this morning killing both pilots, as they have been described in the media. I think it would be true to say, as Senator Morris has suggested, and certainly it is my view, that it is rather unusual for a plane to be departing from Kingsford-Smith Airport at that early hour of the morning when most of the airport, I imagine, would be not particularly active. However, whether small aircraft are outside the curfew arrangements would be a matter that I would have to refer to the Minister for Aviation to see what the circumstances were in respect of the departure of that plane.

ANSWER.PARA: According to the media, the plane was owned by Pelair, which is a company currently the subject of an inquiry by the Papua New Guinea Government. I am not in a position to make any judgment whether there is any connection with that, except that one of the principals involved in the inquiry being conducted in New Guinea was a Mr Aston, a Sydney solicitor, who, according to all the evidence before the various drug inquiries, was very actively involved in that trade. However, I appreciate that there is a curfew operating at Mascot airfield which certainly applies to large aircraft. I will seek information about whether it applies to small aircraft and convey it to Senator Morris in due course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the comment of Professor Jack Richardson on his retirement as Federal Ombudsman. Will the Minister comment on Professor Richardson's statement on the role of the Ombudsman in investigating complaints of public maladministration? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The big disappointment to me has been this Government's refusal to allocate sufficient minimum staff to perform these functions effectively.

Because of the increasingly important role that the Ombudsman plays in administative law in this country, I ask the Minister: Firstly, when will a replacement be announced for Professor Richardson who has already retired and whose retirement was well anticipated? Secondly, will additional investigators be appointed to help clear the backlog of written complaints presently before the Ombudsman? Thirdly, will the Government give urgent consideration to increasing the resources of the Ombudsman's Office in order to reduce the enormous pressure under which its staff are currently working and also to ensure that its excellent record of efficiency is maintained?

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that that question is more appropriately addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, but in either event I will ensure that an answer is obtained for Senator Missen as soon as possible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Trade to a slight on Australian wines which could severely affect sales of the product. The Japanese media have confused Australia with Austria where a component of anti-freeze was added to more than 300 wines as a sweetener. Taken in large quantities, the additive can cause brain and kidney damage. The Japanese media reported that Australian wines had been polluted. In light of this, does the Government intend to ask the Japanese Government to correct the mistake?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The confusion between Austria and Australia is an endemic problem which crops up in various ways. I remember being told by a Minister in the Austrian Government two years ago that it had done a survey of its profile as a nation in the United States and that some 60 per cent of the respondents in the United States confused Australia with Austria, with 70 per cent thinking that the kangaroo came from Austria. So we have a problem, and it has been reflected in the situation in relation to wine in Japan. This issue arose some time ago and I think it is true to say that the Australian authorities in Japan acted with some promptitude. There was, first of all, a general degree of confusion created by television and radio reports in Japan which referred to Australian instead of Austrian wines.

ANSWER.PARA: Following those announcements the Senior Trade Commissioner in charge of marketing in Tokyo issued a media release expressing concern at the mistaken identities and containing assurances from the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation as to the quality of Australian export wine. This was reinforced by direct contact with offending radio and television stations. Briefings were also given by the Senior Trade Commissioner to a number of Japanese newspapers and magazines on the contamination issues. At the request of the Senior Trade Commissioner, the Japanese Government, through the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, also made direct contact with several media networks expressing concern at the mistaken identities and also re-released the Embassy's media release to MITI Press contacts.

A further initiative was a message put out by the Ambassador in Tokyo, Sir Neil Currie, on behalf of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation confirming that Australian wine shipped to Japan does not contain diethyleneglycol, which is the offending substance, as I understand it, to which Senator Foreman referred. Senator Morris will be able to tell me whether I am right. Most major media carried the story in some form. The Senior Trade Commissioner has also proposed a significant advertising campaign in Japan for Australian wine to help turn around the misfortune caused by the wine contamination issue to the advantage of Australian wine. I am pleased to say that the Australian wine industry, including a number of South Australian companies, which would be of concern to the honourable senator who asked the question, are vigorously supporting that campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Leader of the Government. I should say, the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney.

—I congratulate you on your prescience, Mr President. My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, refers to the present Australian Broadcasting Corporation television news and current affairs programming which provides a mix of national and local news and current affairs in State editions of the National and a later night concentration on national and international issues in the centrally-produced Carleton-Walsh Report. Is the Minister aware of any plans to change this format by doing away with local current affairs segments produced as part of evening newscasts in each State? Does the Minister agree that any such plan would be a backward step by the ABC, particularly in more remote States like Western Australia, where he and I come from and where issues which might not interest a Sydney-based producer are nevertheless of great importance to hundreds of thousands of people living outside the major metropolitan centres of eastern Australia?

—I remember hearing what could be described as no more than a rumour to that effect some time ago and I did not follow it up. There may be plans, but I am not aware of them. I will see whether Mr Duffy is and get his response.

—I thank the Minister for that answer. As a supplementary question, I ask him whether he agrees that this would in fact be a backward step for those parts of Australia which lie outside Sydney and Melbourne?
—I rarely see the Perth component of those programs. I do not think that I am in any position to judge.

—I refer the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs to the recent third Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference held in Geneva last month. Will the Minister elaborate on Australian Government participation in the Conference and its contribution to the outcomes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The third NPT Review Conference concluded on 21 September. It was an outstanding success, and it has to be said that the Australian delegation did play a major role in achieving that success. Unlike its predecessor in 1980, the Conference adopted by consensus a substantive final document. That document contains a number of statements of great importance to Australia and the international community. In particular, the Government welcomes: First, the support for International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards for the intensification of safeguards in nuclear weapons states and for an effective international system of plutonium storage; secondly, the clear call on non-parties to join the Treaty and to accept IAEA safeguards in all their nuclear activities, both current and future; thirdly, the call on all states for international nuclear co-operation specifically as a necessary basis for the transfer of nuclear supplies to non-nuclear weapon states to take effective steps to achieve an international, legally binding non-proliferation commitment and the acceptance of full scope safeguards by those states; fourthly, the welcoming of the South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty; and, above all, finally, the clear and unanimous commitment of all non-nuclear weapons states to the cessation of all nuclear testing by all states in all environments for all times and their appeal to the nuclear weapons states to participate in the urgent negotiation and conclusion of such a treaty.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian delegation was instrumental in achieving a number of these results as well as in defusing, through the intervention of the Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, in some early morning shuttle diplomacy, a last minute dispute between Iran and Iraq which did threaten the consensus that had been reached. This Conference was probably the most important international conference to have been held this year, if not for the last few years. I think that it is a matter of pride to record the extent to which Australia's objectives were achieved and the role that Australia played in that Conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of my question is finance and debt but I shall direct it to the Minister representing the Prime Minister because the sources I shall refer to refer to the Prime Minister and because I found the Minister's answer to Senator Sir John Carrick so interesting. I ask the Minister whether Australia is borrowing more money and has far higher debt than most people realise? Are Australians now beginning to grasp the dimensions of their economic difficulties and do they not like what they see? It has been stated that as a result of the Australian dollar being so unstable that it has fallen out of bed. The Prime Minister is losing his ability to control the left wing of his Party. Is the Minister aware that those damning accusations have been made by the bankers attending this week's meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Seoul and appear in the magazine International Investor. What is the Government doing about Australia's drop of 1.8 points in creditworthiness in the last six months alone and a fall of a massive 5.6 points since Mr Hawke came to office in 1983? Is the Minister aware that Australia's credit rating was the third worst performer in the Asian-Pacific group, with Sri Lanka and the Philippines being the only countries to report a bigger drop?

—The question demands a less than simplistic answer; that is to say, the answer has to have a different character from the question. First of all, let me say that I am not aware of all those things which Senator Walters asserts. I do not have the capacities to be able to tell what the average Australian is totally concerned about. If Australians have any concern, they would be concerned about the prospect of a government ever being elected in this country which contained somebody who could ask a question like that. That would be the major concern that most Australians would have at present. Of course the question of Australia's credit rating is of concern to the Government. I am not in a position to agree or disagree about the precise figures which Senator Walters has referred to, but I do not think that the credit rating will be helped by the knowledge that we have that sort of level of political debate in Australia.

—During Question Time today Senator Colston asked me a question and I have found a note on that subject. Mr Hailstone was supervisor of Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Canberra. He was in no way responsible for the decision to take racing services off ABC radio in Canberra, although he was in Canberra at the time the racing service was dropped from the ABC's sport program when commercial station 2CA changed format to become a sports station with a very substantial commitment to race broadcasting. Mr Hailstone was supervisor of radio. Subsequently, commercial station 2CA again changed format after its ratings fell dramatically. The new format excluded all horse racing broadcasts. In view of numerous submissions to the ABC from Canberra racing interests, the decision was then made to return to broadcasting race descriptions on Saturdays and major public holidays only. It is pure coincidence that Mr Hailstone was in senior ABC radio positions in both Brisbane and Canberra when racing broadcasts were discontinued. As has already been pointed out, racing broadcasts were actually reinstated while Mr Hailstone was supervisor of radio in Canberra following the termination of the broadcasting service by the commercial station.
—Mr Deputy President--
—I call the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISITS BY UNITED STATES NAVAL SHIPS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Vallentine asked me:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . how many United States nuclear-capable ship visits to Australia are scheduled in 1986? Secondly, is there to be a significant shift to east coast visits?

As to the first part of the question, the answer is as follows: Government policy on port visits to Australia by United States Navy ships makes no distinction between nuclear capable and non-nuclear capable. As has been stated many times here and in another place this Government accepts the US policy of `neither confirm nor deny'. As to the total of US ship visits to Australia scheduled for 1986, neither US Navy planning nor Australia-US planning is directed towards establishing a precise figure in advance for a calendar year. Some visits, such as those for combined Australian-US exercises can be estimated with reasonable certainty, but the general procedure for proposed visits by US warships to Australian ports is that the US requests approval for a visit some two to three months prior to the proposed date of a particular visit. This request and the processing of it is classified, in order to protect from potentially hostile nations knowledge of US ship movements and operating patterns. Similar procedures apply to Royal Australian Navy ship requests for overseas port visits. If the US ship visit is approved and the US requirement for the visit remains current, information concerning the proposed visit is declassified some 10 days prior to the ship's arrival and a public announcement of the visit is issued.

As to the second part of the question, there is currently a disproportionate number of visits to Western Australia by US Navy ships compared with port visits to the Eastern States. The reason for this is that Western Australian ports are the first landfall in Australia for US ships returning to their home ports in Hawaii and the west coast of the US after extended deployment to the Indian Ocean. The port calls are for rest and recreation. When the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) visited the US in August this year he raised with US authorities the need to change this pattern. Ways of implementing this change are to be discussed on a navy to navy basis with any changes being subject to US Navy requirements and it would not be expected that a substantial change to the pattern could be implemented before late next year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: IMPORTS OF SOUTH AFRICAN RAILWAY EQUIPMENT

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked by Senator Jones a genuine question without notice about the possibility of some railway equipment being imported from South Africa. The Minister for Transport has provided me with this response: The Federal Government has direct responsibility only for the Australian National Railways Commission, known otherwise as AN, and therefore it has no knowledge of any dealings by State rail authorities in this regard. Australian National was advised on 21 August of the policy announced on 19 August by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on dealings with South Africa. AN has advised that no rail equipment originating from South Africa has been contracted for purchases since that date. However, it also advised that it contracted to buy 36 bogies from Bradford Kendall Foundries, a firm based in New South Wales, on 25 February 1985. Tenders were invited in 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: AN understands that a South African firm called Woodmack Corporation was sub-contracted by Bradford Kendall to provide 72 axles and 300 rubber springs for the 36 bogies. These components represented approximately 6 per cent of the total contract price. As the contract was let for less than $2m the approval of the Commowealth Minister for Transport was not required. AN has advised that it is not aware of any other South African involvement. Therefore, the question of any Federal Government action should be taken up with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) as the Minister responsible for the Government's policy with respect to dealings with South Africa. I thank the honourable senator for raising the question. The matter will be dealt with expeditiously by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your indulgence, Mr Deputy President, to inform you of why I was seeking the call. Very early in Question Time I asked a question. The Minister did not have the brief with him. Subsequently, he found it and gave the answer at the end of Question Time. I was going to seek leave to ask a supplementary question but now that the Minister has gone there is no point in doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. The Australian Financial Review last Tuesday carried an article claiming that there were differences between the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and myself on taxation policy. That proposition is just absurd and I would let the matter pass were it not for the fact that in the last day or so the Government has tried to use the article to misrepresent the Opposition's policies. Let me make the position clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Financial Review's report of the interview, particularly the headline, failed to make the point that was clearly understood by the journalist from the outset. The policy of the coalition on tax is the policy laid down prior to the last election. That policy features income splitting for single income families with dependent children, a rebate for child care expenses, a broadening of the indirect tax base, and, I stress, no capital gains tax. That is the policy which Mr Howard and all Opposition members support. Against that fundamental point, all other discussion reported in the article was about the policy review process which the Opposition, through its various committees, is undertaking. The examples mentioned in the article were illustrative only, and were used for the purpose of demonstrating the problems in developing options in the various areas I will mention. For Government spokesmen to elevate such discussions to the status of policy is mischievous and plainly wrong.

Let me deal with each of the main areas raised in the article. I am quoted as saying: `There would be no consumption tax.' This has been taken out of context from discussion about option C of the White Paper on the reform of the Australian Tax System, recently presented by the Treasurer, Mr Keating. The point I made was that the 12 1/2 per cent consumption tax as put forward by Mr Keating would not be acceptable to the Opposition. This mirrors the views expressed in our own policy which mentions gradual and predictable changes to the indirect tax system, and which canvasses options and provides substantial scope for offsetting reductions in personal income tax. The question of whether one or other of the various options canvassed in our policy might be adopted is a matter for policy development and later decision. In the interview I stated that the wholesale sales tax was a logical place to start to examine the options. Similarly, a tax on services is canvassed in our policy as an argument against the regressive nature of indirect taxes. These are quite sensible starting points in our review process.

Mr Keating's hysterical imaginings about my discussions on section 26AAA can only be described as beyond the realms of any kind of reasonable comment, even from such a plainly cynical politician as the Treasurer. Again, the interview with the Australian Financial Review included a discussion of the effects of the application of the present law in sections 25A and section 26AAA. He relied on my expression `modification' in relation to the law. Those modifications were given sinister connotations. They were part of my discussions with the journalist in the context of possible avoidance of the present provisions and centred on the amendments introduced earlier to tighten them. In no way did I suggest that the present law would be in any way modified to extend them into a generalised capital gains tax, such as suggested by the Treasurer. Perhaps only one such as he could devise such a deceitful strategem. I repeat, the Opposition will not introduce a capital gains tax. We will abolish the Australian Labor Party's capital gains tax. There is no truth in the Government's assertions that the tax policy of the Opposition has been changed. Our policy remains in place and I am proud to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Maguire:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this paper because it is a very serious indictment of the state of the aviation industry-in fact, the whole aviation movement-in Australia at the moment. Of course, people outside the industry also fly aeroplanes. I refer specifically to the general aviation section of this paper. Page 23 shows that activity in all but the charter sectors of general aviation is less than it has been in previous peak times. This is directly attributable to the Department of Aviation.

SPEECH.PARA: General aviation is a little recognised component of the whole aviation movement in Australia. General aviation actually has far more flights than the airlines and far more hours are flown. The general aviation sector is very important in rural and outback areas which rely on smaller aircraft for the movement of goods and passengers. General aviation has been hamstrung in recent years by a number of cost increases. One of the major increases is in the cost recovery program of the Department of Aviation, that is, the air navigation charges. I had a Cessna 180 aircraft which was costing $900 a year in air navigation charges. These charges were levied, supposedly, to pay for the costs expended by the Government for my benefit. These costs were not expended for my benefit but for the benefit of the Department of Aviation. I benefited very little from them. All in the general aviation industry are asked to pay for the very bloated bureaucrats in the Department of Aviation who merely wield rubber stamps.

Another difficulty for general aviation is the very restrictive and complicated air traffic control procedures which are presided over by the Department of Aviation. In many instances, the Department's procedures are actually decreasing aircraft safety. All the control zones are in basins around the capital cities, surrounded by mountainous areas. The Department of Aviation, by design, makes it so difficult for a general aviation aircraft to fly into these control zones according to visual flight rules that pilots will often attempt to a avoid the zones in bad weather and, in so doing, will jeopardise the aircraft and the passengers on board with terrible results. Accidents take place often in the mountainous areas surrounding control zones.

The other aspect of the Department of Aviation which is hampering general aviation is the complete lack of rapport between Department of Aviation personnel and the flying public-the general aviation sector. The DOA considers itself a policeman of the regulations-not a co-worker with the pilot in the cockpit-to make sure that the pilot is not in violation. It is well known in aviation circles that if a general aviation aircraft has an accident, it would be wise to have a solicitor draw up the accident report rather than the pilot himself because the Department of Aviation may actually take legal action against any pilot who has an accident.

Another example is the reluctance of general aviation pilots to declare emergencies in flight. One would think that, given the skilled staff of the Department of Aviation-there are some left on the ground in the control towers-a pilot would be very eager to declare an emergency. But this is not so because the Department of Aviation requires a whole series of inquiries upon the declaration of an emergency which may then lead to the loss of licence for the general aviation pilot. I hope that the Department of Aviation takes a good look at its own report and that it takes my remarks to heart because it is stifling general aviation in this country. General aviation deserves to be given far more support than it has been getting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This massive report, reviewing Aboriginal employment and training programs, opens with the comment:

SPEECH.PARA: As we approach the year of Australia's bicentennial celebrations it remains overwhelmingly obvious that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians have little cause for celebration. To say that their employment situation has reached a crisis point would be an understatement. Despite the gains that have been made in some areas, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as a group remain the most disadvantaged people in Australian society.

I believe that we have to take note of this statement. It is a sad indictment that almost 200 years after European settlement on this continent a group of our citizens are faced with chronic long term unemployment, insurmountable health problems and a future that will remain bleak as long as the present out of sight, out of mind view prevails. This report is styled as a blueprint for government support for the Aboriginal people's ability to provide for their livelihood. It issues a severe warning that, without a radical change of direction in government policy and practice, Aboriginals will remain locked in an economic prison where they have been since the coming of European settlers.

Since 1788 Aboriginal society has been confronted with social and economic upheavals. Traditional modes of sustenance, provided by hunting and gathering, have been replaced by sit-down money-a euphemism for government welfare handouts. The drain of these payments on the revenue of the Commonwealth is significant because many Aboriginals remain dependent on this sit-down money from the moment they are born to the moment they die. Presently, Aboriginal people are unemployed at a rate of some five to six times that of the total white Australian labour force. Not long ago, some 23 000 Aboriginal persons were registered by the Commonwealth Employment Service as seeking full time work. How many more Aboriginal persons are there in the community who know that the desperate hopelessness of their prospects of finding work means that they will stay on the dole for a long time and that they will have a guaranteed minimum income on the dole which is unsatisfactory but at level which they are willing to accept?

I wish to mention briefly some historical aspects. Aboriginal society has suffered varying degrees of destruction of the viability of its traditional economy through the loss of land and subsequent dependence on a new economy created by European settlement. The work avail- able for Aboriginals was of a rural, unskilled nature, both seasonal and sporadic. Today the situation is much worse. This is because of declining rural fortunes which have meant that work prospects are non-existent in many areas where there is a large Aboriginal population-areas such as north Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Work prospects in my own State of South Australia remain pretty bleak for Aboriginals. Of particular concern is the plight of traditional communities. These Aboriginals have remained in close contact with the country with which they have a strong cultural bond. To stay in their country they are totally dependent on government funding for wage employment.

What solutions can be found to eliminate these problems? The report states emphatically that the short term solutions currently pursued by government, whilst welcome, are inadequate. The report also states:

Far too little of this assistance was directed towards the enhancement of the long term employment prospects of Aboriginal people or to enabling Aboriginal people to establish and develop the economic bases of their communities.

The report focuses on Aboriginal education. It suggests that flexibility and sensitivity are needed if the education system is not to continue to fail the Aboriginal people. I call upon the Government to implement quickly the recommendations in this review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Senator Coates:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As in the case of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which was established to finance and promote the rural sector of our economy, the Australian Industry Development Corporation's primary objectives are to promote Australian industry and Australian ownership in industry. Its operations are similar to a bank in that it borrows money, lends money and provides corporate advice. However, unlike a bank, the Corporation's Industry Development Division specialises in investment in industry by providing risk capital, especially for start-up situations and for projects involving major expansion or reconstruction. It also attempts to stimulate development in the more positive role of a catalyst and an active investor. I am aware that the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The retention of the AIDC as a government-owned financial intermediary is not necessary for an efficient and competitive financial system.
It stated further:
The AIDC should be disposed of to private sector interests.

With a government hell bent on deregulation and an opposition which seems to believe that privatisation is the solution to most of Australia's economic problems, I wish to put on record that the Australian Democrats support the role currently played by the AIDC. We believe in the importance of keeping government control over this Corporation. I do not believe that the private banks existing in Australia, or the 16 foreign banks which are now entering Australia, can provide the financial assistance that is needed for Australia to develop a strong trading, industrial and technological infrastructure. They are motivated by profit, not by long-term benefit for the Australian economy. Profit is not a dirty word but the blind pursuit of profit is not synonymous with what is good for the Australian economy in the long run.

In a mixed economy it is appropriate for the Government to play a role in setting the pace and direction of economic development. In Australia it is especially important that we aim to reduce the level of foreign ownership of our resources. It is crucial to have an organisation like the AIDC which can foster Australian enterprise and ideas so that these are not sold to foreign companies. It is therefore pleasing to see in this report that Australianism is a significant part of the AIDC's activities. The Corporation has increased Australian equity in existing projects-for example, the Palm Valley natural gas joint venture, referred to on page 34 of the report, and the Hospital Corporation of Australia Pty Ltd, mentioned yesterday by Senator Coates. It is also involved with Mica Pty Ltd and Austek Microsystems Ltd, which are high-tech industries. It has also supported joint ventures to capitalise on breakthroughs in the development of a vaccine against malaria, referred to on page 36. All of these are admirable objectives.

The Corporation makes a profit. It does not require massive government funding and it provides assistance and advice to new enterprises and industries. It has now adopted a new policy of allocating some of its resources to facilitating reconstruction of Australian industry and has set up a special industry restructuring unit to assist in this policy. I do not believe that it is a suitable candidate for privatisation. The AIDC provides assistance that would not come from the private banking sector. It can be directed to help achieve social and economic priorities considered to be important by the government of the day. I believe that it would be utterly short-sighted and disastrous in the long term just to go for a drive for profit or to try to sell the AIDC to the private sector as a banking operation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I had available at the end of yesterday's consideration of this paper, I pointed out that the opinion of the Solicitor-General could not get to the political heart of the matter. The narrow terms of reference confined the nature of the work done by the Solicitor-General at the direction of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The unavailability of all material documents and the inability to pursue recollection of oral undertakings forced Dr Gavan Griffith to qualify the applicability of his answers. It is not yet clear the degree to which the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was monitoring the Australian Bicentennial Authority, although at last night's Senate Estimates Committee A hearing letters were incorporated in the record of proceedings. The Department's information collecting procedures and their accuracy do not appear to be without reproach. It is unclear the extent to which various options were put forward to the Prime Minister, along with the consequences likely to flow from them. This is the problem that pervades the whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears that actions were frequently taken in haste with insufficient information. This is a major reason why large sums of money and staff time are being spent analysing the problem areas that remain, especially political ones. The bureaucrats claim that their requests for information were not properly met. Authority staff say that replies were given much earlier than the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has acknowledged. The media have relied on leaks and recycled Press releases. Only with yesterday's Senate Estimates Committee hearings are we beginning to get at the matters of enduring concern.

We need to know about the progress of getting corporate involvement in the funding of the 1988 celebrations. We need to know what efforts are being made to encourage voluntary input by fostering people-directed programs of a creative nature. We need to know what has been done and what will be done to involve the people and governments of countries such as Greece, Italy and Yugoslavia in the Bicentennial. We need to know what guidelines operate when consultants are considered or briefed. We need to encourage the Authority's Board members to seek organisational structures which will enable them to have early access to information. We need to make it the natural thing that people want to participate in community activities in 1988. It is important that all Australians feel that it is worth while participating in Bicentennial activities.

I find it hard to see how one can make rock hard pronouncements two years before the whole process is due to come together. We have to keep a watchful eye on the structure of the Authority and the reasons why things are being done. It is very important that we have more than one body looking at what is happening in these areas. We must not discourage those employees of the Authority who are putting all they have into the work.

We have to take the debate away from personalities, scapegoats and tired red herrings such as this exercise that an embattled Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has belatedly foisted on the Solicitor-General. I hope that we can interest the media also in the thousand-million-dollar stories such as the shambles of Australia's purported offsets policy or the opportunity for Telecom Australia to use its buying muscle to foster an Australian electronic manufacturing industry, rather than just a quarter of a million dollar exercise which involves a couple of personalities and an Authority which is currently under siege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Solicitor-General's opinion is dated 8 October. That is precisely eight weeks after the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority to sever the employment of the Chief Executive, and six weeks after the severance was complete. The opinion has emerged only because in mid-September the Prime Minister was thoroughly embarrassed by the exposure of the amount of the settlement and has sought devices and contrivances to separate himself from the decisions. Whether or not the Solicitor-General's opinion is correct-that is a matter of disputation-it stands as a damning comment on the Prime Minister. It proves his dereliction of duty; that he has misled the Parliament and the people; that he has not been in contact with his own Department; and that he has been grossly inefficient in his administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put the headlands in a brief statement. On 15 August the Prime Minister told the Chairman of the Authority to sever the employment of the Chief Executive. The Chairman had no grounds for it and told the Prime Minister that there were no grounds for severance based on misconduct. He said that it would have to be by negotiation and a settlement would have to be negotiated. The Prime Minister told the Chairman to go ahead and do it. That is beyond dispute. On 19 August the Chairman sent a facsimile letter to the Prime Minister which stated that he had done what the Prime Minister had asked him to do. It said: `Here are the proposed methods of doing it'. It set out in detail the needs and ingredients in the settlement and the restraints to be applied. Then the Prime Minister, in a phone call, commended him for the letter and the details and told him to err on the side of generosity. The Chairman said: `I am glad you said that, Mr Prime Minister, because it will be expensive; it will be more than $400,000'. The Prime Minister confirmed that.

On 28 August the Chairman sent a letter to the Prime Minister setting out the precise details and asking for the method of appropriation of funds-whether out of general funds or special appropriation. On 30 August the Prime Minister replied-not criticising one iota of the details-telling the Chairman to get on with the job and settle. That is precisely what the Chairman did. It happens that he has now discovered that at no time did the Department know about the letter or conversation of 19 August or the letter of 28 August. In other words, at every step the Prime Minister was instructing in detail what was to be done. Subsequently he came out and said: `I had nothing to do with it; it was the Chairman'. He recently said: `We never got a copy of the letter of appointment'. Last night we found out that of course he did, that it had been in the Department. Once again the Prime Minister was wrong.

The Prime Minister, without giving any reasons why a man's employment should be severed, has not stopped even to find out the terms of employment or to get the advice of the Solicitor-General or anybody else, has not informed his Department and has totally misled the people of Australia. This opinion stands as a document pointing to the dereliction of duty of the Prime Minister, the complete inefficiency of his administration and the complete breakdown between his Department and himself. He has attempted to make a scapegoat out of the Chairman, a man who has an immensely high reputation in this country, but he has been caught in his own trap. It is not the Chairman who stands here convicted; it is the Prime Minister, convicted by the evidence which comes out day by day and which proves that virtually everything he has said is wrong and that he was the negotiator and the manipulator step by step of something that he tried to pass to others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Among the many interesting elements of this opinion is the fact that it explodes one of the excuses that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used in making Mr Reid a scapegoat for his own disgraceful and incompetent behaviour in the matter of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. The interesting point that emerges here is that the Prime Minister said in the House of Representatives on 8 October that for a variety of reasons he formed the view that the only motive for `the composition of the settlement was tax minimisation'. That view is, of course, exploded by the opinion of the same date, which says that the Authority was in the view of the Solicitor-General entitled to act and rely on the advice from Allen Allen and Hemsley.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at this whole saga of the Prime Minister's actions-quite apart from the questions that Senator Sir John Carrick raised: The Prime Minister clearly misled the House; his Department was in possession of letters-we see that by having a belated reliance on advice the Prime Minister has in effect exposed his own lack of competence. The Senate will recall that the Prime Minister made no effort either to establish what was the basis on which Dr Armstrong was employed or to seek to gain any legal advice when this matter was settled, as I recall it, on 28 August. The reason he did not either seek advice or look at the letter which was in his Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, for which he is allegedly responsible, is very simple. At that stage there was a hope that this deal would be kept secret and that it would not be available to scrutiny by the Senate until the next lot of hearings of the Senate Estimates committees and that the matter would by then have blown over. The reality is that it did not blow over and that the facts escaped. The Prime Minister then floundered around looking for a scapegoat. The impressive feature of this document is that it reveals that the Chairman of the Authority should not be the scapegoat but that the person who is responsible surely must be the Minister in charge of the Authority, and that of course is the Prime Minister.

It is curious to read through the opinion as amended on the 8th-it was originally given to the Prime Minister on the 3rd-and to compare it with the Prime Minister's justification for objecting to what happened and trying to provide Mr Reid as the scapegoat. The claim that the only motive for the composition of the settlement was tax minimisation is an absolutely disgraceful allegation which cannot be sustained. I believe that the solicitors involved have today presented to the Board of the ABA their view of the Solicitor-General's opinion. The fact remains that the Solicitor-General's opinion does not support tax minimisation being the prime cause that the Prime Minister used to find a scapegoat for this affair.

As Senator Sir John Carrick quite properly pointed out, there was no attempt to mislead the Prime Minister. His own incompetence misled him and this was evident from his failure to look at the letter of appointment that was in his own Department's file all the time. It had been there from the time the Prime Minister's Department took over the running of the Authority at the beginning of this year. That letter resided under his own authority. He was not sufficiently competent as an administrator to be aware of it and he has misled the House by saying that it was not in his possession. If he did not have it it was not because of any misleading by Mr Reid but because of his own incredible incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Watson:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the annual report of the National Debt Commission was adjourned I was saying that expenditure on debt sinking funds had grown exponentially. From 11 August 1923 to 30 June 1980 the total expenditure for debt redemption was approximately $8.7 billion-that is in 57 years. However, in the year 1980-81 it was $1.45 billion and in 1984-85 it was $1.125 billion. A similar pattern has developed in relation to the public debt of the States. The Commonwealth has to bear a proportion of these costs because of the financial agreements with the States. As large as Australia's public sector debt is, it is minuscule compared with the total domestic and foreign debt which Australia must bear in the future. The National Debt Commission is not responsoble for the billions of dollars borrowed at home and overseas by Telecom Australia, Trans Australia Airlines, the State electricity commissions and a number of other semi-governmental authorities, and that debt is enormous.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Debt Commission's report makes no mention of the massive overseas borrowings made by Australian business in funding the non-existent resources boom during the Fraser Government years. It also makes no mention of the current boom in overseas borrowings by people such as Mr Bond, who borrowed from Hong Kong in order to buy out Australian companies such as Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd. Treasury figures estimate that foreign debt totalled $68.5 billion at 30 June this year. This is likely to increase. In these troubled economic times, with a limp unit of currency, borrowing money with no regard as to the capacity to repay is a foolish exercise. We must be careful not to saddle our children and their children with debts which will destroy their way of life and not allow them to beneift from the same advantages as we enjoy.

While the public sector share of the foreign debt has dropped from 51 per cent to 38 per cent, this cannot be an excuse for complacency. The private sector debt is now much higher. We must remain vigilant and remember that finding money to pay for public debt and the Government's great programs may decimate the fixed interest borrowing market in Australia to the detriment of other borrowers in the market. This will particularly affect business borrowers who have been forced, and will be forced, to look overseas for more moneys which are not available on the domestic market. It is detrimental to all Australians for us to have a large public debt. It is detrimental to all Australians for us to have a large foreign debt. Every step of more borrowing by organisations within the Government sector takes us further along the slippery road to an Argentinian-type economy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
