PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 October 1984, on motion by Senator Hill:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend my colleague Senator Hill on his initiative in bringing forward this private member's Bill on horticultural plant variety rights. Unfortunately, the Horticultural-Plant Variety Rights Bill 1984 [1985] is fairly restricted. It differs greatly from the Bill which was presented to the Senate several years ago by a then Liberal Government because today's Bill covers only horticulture-products such as fruit, vegetables and ornamentals. We have before us an amendment to be moved by the Australian Democrats attempting to further restrict the application of the Bill. I must acknowledge that I can see a minor problem with the Bill in that I believe that there is a lack of definition of horticulture as such. I think this is intentional because horticulture is both a generic and a scientific term. However, that must raise some questions as to the Bill's coverage, particularly at the margin. For example, of whether an item is a horticultural or a field crop type variety. My colleague Senator Hill, I believe, will be able to advise the Senate adequately of the reasons for this approach.

SPEECH.PARA: I, together with others, have received hundreds of letters-many of which have emanated from South Australia, Senator Hill's State, supporting the establishment of a Commonwealth-wide scheme for plant variety rights in relation to horticulture. The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources concluded that plant variety rights was the most appropriate means of bringing access to overseas varieties and stimulating plant breeding in Australia. Unfortunately, plant variety rights is yet another blind spot in the Labor Government's attitude towards Australian agriculture. The benefits are quite clear, yet the Government continues to procrastinate on this important issue. I remind the Senate that I do not believe the issue to be entirely dead, even within the Australian Labor Party. I understand that in July of this year the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, in taking note of the views expressed by the two dissenting Labor Party senators-in the senate report of May 1984, appointed the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania, Professor Alec Lazenby, a noted agriculturalist, to investigate plant breeding needs in Australia.

I believe that the Government owes us an explanation as to the inquiry's terms of reference. They appeared to be fairly restrictive, according to what was reported in the Australian Financial Review in July this year. However, I am led to believe that the inquiry is well under way, with Professor Lazenby and his advisers already meeting interested groups in most States. Although two Labor senators on the Senate Committee's inquiry presented a dissenting report, even they recommended that a plant variety rights scheme be implemented to cover ornamentals. Therefore, this Bill should fit very neatly their needs and I would expect unanimous support around the chamber, including from the Democrats, for this important Bill introduced by my colleague Senator Hill.

Unfortunately, much of the Opposition to plant variety rights appears to centre on the need for merit testing. Given the very significant differences in climate around Australia and the great variety of soil types and structures, merit testing might not always provide the sort of protection the promoters seek. Clause 24 of Senator Hill's Bill provides for test growing of plant varieties in circumstances where, on receipt of the application, the secretary could consider it necessary that there should be a test growing or a further test growing for the purpose of determining homogeneity or whether the variety grown in Australia would have particular characteristics. That should surely satisfy most of the doubting Thomases.

Today's Bill will establish procedures to collect royalties on the sale of new plant varieties they develop which have the PVR required characteristics of uniformity, stability, homogeneity, and so on. Plant variety rights as such differ from patent rights in that the right is conferred only on the end product and not on the process by which it is produced. PVR legislation enables individuals, companies or institutions to gain property rights over propagating materials, seed cuttings, root stocks et cetera and provides the owner with the legal right to exclude others from selling seeds of that variety, reproducing them, except for their own use, and importing or exporting the product. A registered variety may be used freely for research purposes and can be sold or ownership transferred to another person, company or institution, as with other forms of property. To be registered, a variety must have been orginated by a person and not merely discovered and must be distinct from known varieties, uniform in population and stable over repeated generations. The horticultural PVR Bill embodies all these concepts, which is welcomed.

Although there is a claim that PVR could raise the cost of certain seeds, I believe that, generally, buyers are very conscious, in making their acquisitions, of what we might term a cost-benefit analysis in that they will not purchase these seeds unless they produce significantly greater yields than other seeds. Much has also been said about multinational companies operating in this area acquiring a stranglehold in Third World countries. But most Third World countries do not have PVR. Further, most seeds sold by multinational operations to the Third World would result in increased productivity, which surely provides a benefit to all concerned. A matter of some criticism of plant variety rights is that they can also lead to genetic erosion in Third World countries. However, Australia imports only very small samples of Third World varieties for development in Australia.

I digress to consider some of the wider issues. Although not covered by this Bill, broad acre crops, pastures, wheat and so on are also important to Australia. In the context of the erosion of the genetic base I mention that the Australian wheat collection in Tamworth amounts to some 20,000 varieties and it is increasing all the time. Furthermore the Australian Agricultural Council has examined proposals for genetic banks to maintain genetic resourses in Australia and I think that sort of argument refutes all the doubts arising in this area.

A further concern of the anti-PVR lobby is the fear that the large corporations will breed varieties with a very high level of chemical dependency, thereby raising the costs for farmers. Such an argument ignores the relativity that it is far more cost effective to build in disease resistance to varieties than to undertake expensive testing of chemicals required before marketing. This ability to build in disease resistance is one of the very important features which could be afforded to Australian producers as a result of a proper plant variety rights scheme. The fear of the multinationals buying out the seed firms overlooks the fact that there are very few major Australian-owned seed firms. I suppose that the major exception would be Yates, but even that passed under the control of Cheetham Salt the other day. Most smaller firms operating in Australia seem to be able to co-exist alongside the multinationals. I raise those matters because I believe the answers that I have provided well and truly squash the arguments that our opponents are likely to raise against this Bill.

Most developed countries, including Germany, France, the United Kingdom, the United States, the Soviet Union, Japan, Mexico and Israel, have instituted statutory rights for plant breeders. In fact, a plant variety rights Act was passed in New Zealand way back in 1973 and the following decade has seen a 500 per cent increase in private investment in plant breeding for that country giving access to new plant varieties which are developed overseas. Those figures spell volumes for the need for plant variety rights and, coming from Tasmania, I wholeheartedly support the need for such a measure. New Zealand has seen a continuing expansion in commercial plant breeding and this has given a boost to its export seed trade as well as bringing in royalties from the cultivars market overseas. It has resulted in increased co-operation between farmers, the commercial seed trade and the Government.

Currently private breeding here in Australia is largely based on hybrid varieties which, by virtue of their characteristics, have an in-built protection. Breeding schemes for open-pollinated crops, such as wheat, are conducted largely through levies paid by the growers and in the public sector. Unfortunately in a wide range of crops and vegetables such levies do not exist and, also, public plant breeding programs have been neglected. This is one of the main concerns that we have in Tasmania, as our State is a major horticultural producer. At the same time, Australian growers have been hampered in that they have been denied access to varieties of fruit and vegetables that have been available overseas for years. In the absence of PVR legislation, vegetable seed companies have been forced to turn to hybrid seeds in order to protect their interests.

Furthermore, important new varieties are being denied to Australian growers and, according to Mr Hugh Bishop of the South Australian Fruit Growers Market Gardeners Association Incorporated, it is clear that overseas institutions are adopting a far tougher stand to the extent that even the entry of material for research and evaluation has now been denied to us. That is an opinion from your own State, Madam Acting Deputy President. We are losing our competitiveness in both domestic and overseas markets by not being able to adapt to meet changing market demands and this is having a devastating effect on fruit and vegetable growers.

To illustrate the problems associated with the lack of PVR legislation, I would like to remind the Senate about the problems facing Tasmanian pea growers. Pea growers are facing disastrous price reductions of up to 30 per cent for the 1985-86 season. In real terms, the reduction means cuts of more than 50 per cent in the profits from pea crops and thousands of tonnes of peas being ploughed back into the rich Tasmanian soil. Pea growers blame the reduction in profit and acreage on imports of cheap peas, particularly from New Zealand. To add to this, most of the seeds used by Edgells are bred in New Zealand and imported into Australia. Growers have no option but to use these seeds. New Zealand has PVR, of course, and we do not.

The gross value of all vegetable production each year in our small State of Tasmania is close to $60m; so it is absolutely vital that these industries remain competitive and viable. Professor M. G. Mullins, Professor of Horticulture at the University of Sydney, has spoken of several new varieties of fruit being available in the United States that would greatly benefit growers in Australia. These include self-compatible cherries, genetic dwarf peaches and new grape varieties, including some high quality seedless table grapes. In addition, there are new varieties of grapes from Germany, cherries from the United Kingdom and garden beans, strawberries, pome fruits, peaches, nectarines and apricots from the United States that are being refused to growers in Australia because the owners of the new highly marketable varieties would have no protection as we have no PVR legislation.

To accentuate the problem, fruit and vegetable improvement is among the least favoured areas of government-sponsored research because it is long term, speculative, labour intensive and therefore costly. The few varieties of fruit and vegetables that have been introduced into Australia recently have not lived up to expectations, being neither suited to our different climatic conditions nor able to resist plant pests and diseases as well as the locally developed varieties. For Australia to maintain and develop its horticultural industries it must invest massive amounts of capital, expertise and energy into its own plant breeding programs. However, Commonwealth funds for breeding and research have declined markedly since 1976-77. This also came out in the separate report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources.

We have failed in the past to prepare for the future. In so many industries throughout this country we have ceased to be competitive on both the domestic and overseas markets. Some manufacturers have only themselves to blame for not keeping up with changes in technology. The dairy and sugar industries have fought and lost the battle, at least for the moment, with heavily subsidised dumped products from the European Economic Community. Lobbying for a plant variety rights scheme in Australia was initiated in the early 1970s. However, horticulturists have been sold short by successive governments' inaction on PVR legislation. Such legislation would allow them access to new and improved varieties of plants from overseas which would encourage the private sector to become much more active in plant breeding.

The costs involved in plant breeding are considerable, as I mentioned earlier. A lack of private breeding in open-pollinated groups due to high costs has been cited as costing not less than $100,000. Unfortunately, with PVR the breeder loses control of the plant production after its first commercial release. The cost factor plus the loss of capital are seen as significant disincentives for private plant breeding and the Australian economy will therefore be the loser. I believe quite firmly that the evidence in favour of PVR is irrefutable. This new Bill, although it is based on 1982 legislation, and is restrictive in character in that it relates only to horticulture, incorporates many of the relevant recommendations of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. It has the full backing of the horticultural industry. I would commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Horticultural-Plant Variety Rights Bill appears to be based broadly on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources tabled in May 1984. I say `broadly' because it is not as tightly worded as were the recommendations of that report. For example, this Bill does not clearly define `plant'. The Senate Committee report pointed out that the conventional biological definition includes fungi and algae. I doubt whether algae could be regarded as horticulture, but mushrooms might, and the Bill does not make it clear what it covers. The Senate Committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in any PVR legislation the interpretation section include definitions of the words `plant', `cultivar' and `tree'.

Neither does this Bill spell out clearly enough the criteria for determining novelty, surely very important when novelty is an essential ingredient of any patenting scheme. Of course, plant variety rights is a form of patenting scheme. The question of newness or novelty is very complex. In fact it occupies over a page of the Committee's report in summary form. As a result, that report recommended:
. . . in any PVR legislation the criteria for determining `newness' or `novelty' be clarified.

This Bill's title refers to horticultural plants, but I was unable-maybe I did not look hard enough-to find the definition of horticulture, at least in the interpretation clause of the Bill. The main reason for opposing this Bill, quite apart from any objections to the substance or purpose of it, is that the whole question of plant breeding needs in Australia is the subject of a current inquiry. This Government is committed under Australian Labor Party policy not to introduce any scheme for plant variety rights without an inquiry into Australia's plant breeding needs and all other alternatives to PVR. In fact I think it refers to a searching inquiry. It was considered by the Government and by the Committee, at least in the matter of public plant breeding and the more technical, scientific considerations involved in the PVR issue, that the Senate Committee inquiry needed to be supplemented by an independent expert inquiry. For that reason an inquiry was set up of which the specific terms of reference are these:

Having regard to debate on the possible introduction of a Plant Variety Rights scheme into Australia, and the need to ensure that plant breeding remains responsive to industry needs and receptive to changes in technology, investigate and report by 31 January 1986 on Australia's plant breeding needs and all other alternatives to PVR.
In carrying out its work, the Inquiry examination include the following specific areas-
(a) the adequacy of the current plant breeding effort, both public and private;
(b) any deficiencies and imbalances in the current programs;
(c) where needs are identified under (a) and (b),
the expected impact on those needs of the possible introduction of PVR;
Surely that is very important. To continue:
(d) options available to overcome any problems identified under (a) or (b);
(e) what adjustments, if any, should be made to public plant breeding programs if PVR were introduced;
(f) the desirability of public plant breeders being encouraged to compete with private sector breeders in variety development and, if desirable, the options available to effect this; and
(g) the alternatives to PVR for stimulating private plant breeding activity.

The inquiry is being conducted by Professor Alex Lazenby, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania, who has had a distinguished career in agricultural research, including several years research experience in the United Kingdom. As was mentioned just now, the United Kingdom is a country with some years experience of a plant variety rights scheme. The inquiry is technical in nature and thus has not advertised for submissions, but the inquiry does have access to the transcripts and submissions of the Senate Committee and will be able to contact those witnesses and any other individual or group who has expressed interest in plant breeding or in plant variety rights. Professor Lazenby has been asked to report early next year in time for his report to be considered by the Australian Agricultural Council which, of course, is a council of Ministers from the States as well as the Commonwealth, at its next meeting in February.

While this inquiry is underway it seems to me that the introduction of a private member's Bill covering the same matter is either an attempt to pre-empt the report of that inquiry or-and I put the kindest interpretation on it-an attempt to gain publicity for the cause that Senator Hill is espousing. It is indicative of the degree of knowledge of many of those writing in support of the Bill that not one writer of letters I have received seemed aware that I was on record as an opponent of PVR. Senator Georges and I dissented from the National Resources Committee report. Had they read the report at all, they surely would have at least noticed who were the authors of the dissent, even if they were reluctant to read it. It follows from what I have just said that I am not going to debate the issues which are within the terms of reference of Professor Lazenby's inquiry.

I will, however, speak briefly about some of the other matters which are regularly raised or have been raised in much of the recent correspondence in favour of the introduction of PVR for horticulture. I am assuming, in the absence of a clear definition in the Bill, that horticulture covers fruit, vegetables and possibly herbs. If it also includes ornamentals, I do not have any difficulty with plant variety rights for ornamentals, although I know that there is in some quarters a fear that that would provide the thin end of the wedge. However, I did not, as Senator Watson stated, recommend PVR for ornamentals. In fact I will read the actual recommendation in the dissenting report:

We recommend that any PVR scheme be restricted to ornamentals and that other means be investigated (for example improved marketing procedures) to overcome the difficulties claimed as the rationale for PVR.

There is a difference between those two statements. The main argument in correspondence I have received in support of Senator Hill's Bill-no doubt other honourable senators have also received correspondence-is that the introduction of new varieties would be facilitated and that new varieties would bring better efficiency and a larger market. New varieties are being developed in Australia. I certainly would support the maintenance and increase of breeding research, particularly public sector research. But that is a matter for the current inquiry, so I will not go further into it. Incidentally, some companies are successfully competing on overseas markets with seeds produced from varieties currently available in Australia. One Melbourne company told me that the seed export business could be greatly expanded with improved production and marketing techniques.

Many varieties of fruit and vegetables available in the past and popular with consumers have disappeared from the market place or at least from the usual suburban shop or supermarket, not because they are inferior but because they do not keep or package well over long periods. The obvious example is the tomato. The Floridade tomato was produced for supermarket convenience and profit with no thought at all for taste. It is now very difficult to buy other varieties, at least in the cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that? Don't you want tomatoes that keep?

—Because they do not taste of anything. On the other hand, the locally bred varieties of tomato, some of the best of which were produced by the Burnley Horticultural Institute in Victoria, are keenly sought in seedling form by the home gardener because they taste like tomatoes. Unfortunately they are very hard to buy in the shops. The much-cited New Zealand nectarine supposedly sought by consumers is selling well through good marketing techniques and because they look good, but most nectarine lovers-and I include myself in those-buy them only once and then return to the better tasting, white flesh varieties-when they can find them. The New Zealanders are very good at marketing their products. Local growers took a while to take up the challenge of the kiwi fruit. The name change from chinese goose- berry was itself clever marketing. Perhaps we should be selling kangaroo fruit or even wombat berries. But the main problem, I believe, is a shrinking overseas market, not confined to horticulturals. The dairying and sugar cane industries have probably been worse hit by the virtual exclusion from the European market. New varieties will not help there unless we switch to the tropical and semi-tropical fruits which cannot be grown in Europe. The most commonly sold varieties of apple in Europe are still granny smiths and jonathans, but they are not ours. I can remember when we in Victoria used to look forward to the arrival of the Tasmanian apples, particularly the Cox's orange pippins, and I am sure that the market would still be there but is not being sought or exploited. Certainly this Bill is an advance on the 1982 Bill of the previous Government, but I cannot support it and the Government will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Horticultural-Plant Variety Rights Bill introduced by Senator Hill is aimed at establishing an Australia-wide scheme for the granting of proprietary rights to plant breeders over any new horticultural varieties which may be developed in Australia. The issue of plant variety rights is a complex one and throughout the numerous occasions on which the issue has arisen in this chamber the Australian Democrats have shown that they recognise that complexity. In 1982 the Democrats decided to oppose the Plant Variety Rights Bill, but later in that same year we supported an investigation into plant variety rights by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. We recognised that the issue needed to be examined in depth.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators will be aware, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources presented a lengthy report, with 22 recommendations. The major one was that the Commonwealth consider the introduction of a plant variety scheme in Australia. The Australian Democrats believed then, as we do now, that while the Senate Committee report considerably advanced discussions in this area, it did not provide the foundation for suitable legislation. We pointed out that the report had not established that the introduction of plant variety rights would provide a general benefit for most Australians. Indeed the Committee, while concluding that plant variety rights was the most appropriate means of improving access to overseas varieties, conceded that the funding and direction of public breeding activity under PVR were issues that had not been adequately addressed in evidence to the Committee.

The Democrats' concern that the Committee's major recommendation could not be supported has been vindicated by overseas studies. The report by Dr L. J. Butler from the Department of Agricultural Economics at the University of Wisconsin, entitled `An Economic Evaluation of the Plant Variety Protection Act' was completed in the United States of America in 1983. It seems to be the only reputable statement upon which Australia could project what might happen here. The report states:

The alleged benefits to be gained from PVR-namely, stimulation of cross-breeding research-have been realised only in soya beans and, to a lesser extent, wheat. There is no evidence that the Plant Variety Protection Act has triggered large investment in plant breeding research and development, nor of large improvements in either techniques or in plant quality.

While benefits from PVR do not seem to be anything but extremely modest, the fact that Australia has relied on public plant breeding must be taken into consideration. If the introduction of PVR led to a reduction in government funding, significant detriment could be suffered by the wider Australian community, because we depend on government research for the development of many of our new breeding programs. The possibility of dividing basic research, to be conducted by the public sector, from practical plant breeding, to be conducted by the private sector, could very well lead to a disastrous situation for Australian agriculture. A statement by Dr D. H. B. Sparrow, reader in plant breeding at the Waite Agricultural Research Institute in my State, is illustrative of what might happen. He said:

For example Australian soils are deficient in several trace elements. Recently, work at the Waite Institute has demonstrated some barley varieties are better able than others to obtain the trace element manganese from deficient soils. Because this ability appears to be heritable, a programme is now under way to determine the nature of this character and to attempt to transfer improved varieties to deficient soils.
He continued:
This needs a long term study which may or may not pay off and would not attract private investment.
We must not allow the introduction of plant variety rights to cut down government expenditure on research into agriculture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is arguing for that?

—I am just saying that it could be a possible consequence of this Bill. The Democrats believe that the possible divorcement of practical plant breeding from teaching responsibilities and post-graduate research could well mean that the overall level of skill in research and development undertaken in Australia could be effectively reduced while the actual volume of research increased. In other words, the simple increase in research does not necessarily mean that there will be tangible benefits for the consumer or the grower. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics seems to agree when, with regard to the possible benefits of an increase in plant breeding research, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: This argument assumes that increases in the research effort would generate net gains to society, however this point cannot be easily established by economic analysis.

The evidence presented in the Senate Committee report in relation to the benefits that may accure to Australia seems at best to be ambivalent. The fact that the overwhelming majority of recently successful Australian patents have been held by overseas interests suggests that if plant variety rights are introduced it will be the overseas-based agricultural corporations that will have the most to gain from PVR in Australia and not the Australian community.

The Democrats believe that the Government has the capacity to negotiate with overseas countries for the establishment of appropriate methods that will allow Australia access to overseas plant varieties which are alleged to have been denied to Australian growers because of the lack of PVR. The Democrats believe, as we did under the previous Government, that if the Parliament is called upon to address itself to legislation in this area, it ought to have detailed documentation and the right information to be able to make the right decisions in this area and not just be given assertions the Australia has been denied access. I have no evidence, and I hope that Senator Hill will be able to present us with some, of cases where this access to plants has been denied. There must be ways other than PVR to obtain access to those plants.

The Senate Standing Committee's report failed to provide such documentation. Indeed, the appendices provided by the Department of Primary Industry are couched in identical terms to those of the previous Liberal-National Party Government when it brought before the Parliament its legislation, which was referred to the Committee on 15 September 1982. As the Democrats pointed out during the second reading debate on that legislation, simple checks on that material revealed errors of fact. It is not material upon which the Senate should be asked to determine the value of PVR. The documentation required ought to go beyond the citation of restrictions and ought to give details of the requests, the reasons for denials and under what legislation those denials were made.

It was not until March this year that the Government responded to the Committee's report. The Government noted that the sensitivity of the subject was reflected in the fact that two members of the Committee tabled a minority report. In relation to the major recommendation of the report, to which I referred earlier, the Government decided to establish an inquiry to examine plant breeding needs in Australia and the options for upgrading the public plant breeding program.

In July, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) announced-as was mentioned by Senator Zakharov-that he had appointed Professor Alec Lazenby, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania, to undertake an inquiry. This inquiry will be technical in nature and supplementary to the Senate Standing Committee inquiry. Professor Lazenby has been asked to report in time for the next Australian Agricultural Council meeting in February 1986. I might say in passing that in many ways this debate today is inappropriate. A much-needed inquiry is being conducted; yet we are debating the issue before the findings of the inquiry are available. I support Senator Zakharov's statements in that regard. However, the Democrats are not willing to go so far as to say that the baby should be thrown out with the bath water. This is why we have decided to support a pilot program which will actually show us some of the difficulties of administration with regard to ornamentals, which I believe are enormous. Unless we have the evidence, which we can find out only through practical experience by using the ornamentals as an example, we will not get anywhere. Many arguments have been put to us by supporting organisations to try to dissuade us from taking this course of action. I do not necessarily agree with all of those arguments. Rather than take up the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Australian Conservation Foundation which sets out admirably most of these objections.
Leave granted.
